**Stockholm** (
Swedish: [\[ˈstɔ̂kː(h)ɔlm\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Swedish "Help:IPA/Swedish") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/f/fb/Sv-Stockholm.ogg/Sv-Stockholm.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Sv-Stockholm.ogg "File:Sv-Stockholm.ogg")^)^[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [most populous city](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_Sweden_by_population "List of urban areas in Sweden by population") of [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden"), as well as the [largest urban area in the Nordic countries](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_Nordic_countries "List of urban areas in the Nordic countries"). Approximately 1 million people live in the [municipality](/wiki/Stockholm_Municipality "Stockholm Municipality"),^[\[11\]](#cite_note-SCB2014-11)^ with 1.6 million in the [urban area](/wiki/Stockholm_urban_area "Stockholm urban area"),^[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)^ and 2.4 million in the [metropolitan area](/wiki/Metropolitan_Stockholm "Metropolitan Stockholm").^[\[11\]](#cite_note-SCB2014-11)^ The city stretches across fourteen islands where [Lake Mälaren](/wiki/M%C3%A4laren "Mälaren") flows into the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea"). Outside the city to the east, and along the coast, is the island chain of the [Stockholm archipelago](/wiki/Stockholm_archipelago "Stockholm archipelago"). The area has been settled since the [Stone Age](/wiki/Stone_Age "Stone Age"), in the 6th millennium BC, and was founded as a city in 1252 by Swedish statesman [Birger Jarl](/wiki/Birger_Jarl "Birger Jarl"). The city serves as the county seat of [Stockholm County](/wiki/Stockholm_County "Stockholm County").{#cite_ref-SCB2014_11-1}

Stockholm is the cultural, media, political, and economic centre of Sweden. The Stockholm region alone accounts for over a third of the country's [GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product"),^[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)^ and is among the top 10 regions in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe") by [GDP per capita](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita "List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-14)^ Considered a [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city"),^[\[15\]](#cite_note-15)^ it is the largest in [Scandinavia](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia") and the main centre for [corporate headquarters](/wiki/Corporate_headquarters "Corporate headquarters") in the Nordic region.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-16)^ The city is home to some of Europe's top-ranking universities, such as the [Karolinska Institute](/wiki/Karolinska_Institute "Karolinska Institute") (medicine), [KTH Royal Institute of Technology](/wiki/KTH_Royal_Institute_of_Technology "KTH Royal Institute of Technology"), [Stockholm School of Economics](/wiki/Stockholm_School_of_Economics "Stockholm School of Economics") and [Stockholm University](/wiki/Stockholm_University "Stockholm University").^[\[17\]](#cite_note-17)^ It hosts the annual [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") ceremonies and banquet at the [Stockholm Concert Hall](/wiki/Stockholm_Concert_Hall "Stockholm Concert Hall") and [Stockholm City Hall](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Hall "Stockholm City Hall"). One of the city's most prized museums, the [Vasa Museum](/wiki/Vasa_Museum "Vasa Museum"), is the most visited museum in Scandinavia.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-18)^ The [Stockholm metro](/wiki/Stockholm_metro "Stockholm metro"), opened in 1950, is well known for the decor of its stations; it has been called the longest art gallery in the world.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-19)^ The city was the host of the [1912 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1912_Summer_Olympics "1912 Summer Olympics"), and has played host to several other international sports events since.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-20)^{#cite_ref-20}

Stockholm is Sweden's primary [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre"), one of the largest in Scandinavia, and hosts several of Sweden's largest companies. Furthermore, the headquarters of most of Sweden's largest banks are in Stockholm. Stockholm is one of Europe's major tech centres; the city has sometimes been called Europe's innovation hub.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-eurocompanyformations.com-21)^ The Stockholm region has a GDP of around $180 billion,^[\[22\]](#cite_note-22)^ and Stockholm County has the [highest GDP per capita](/wiki/List_of_Swedish_counties_by_GDP "List of Swedish counties by GDP") of all [counties in Sweden](/wiki/Counties_of_Sweden "Counties of Sweden").^[\[23\]](#cite_note-23)^{#cite_ref-23}

Stockholm is the seat of the [Swedish government](/wiki/Government_of_Sweden "Government of Sweden") and most of [its agencies](/wiki/Government_agencies_in_Sweden "Government agencies in Sweden"),^[\[24\]](#cite_note-24)^ including the highest courts in the [judiciary](/wiki/Judiciary_of_Sweden "Judiciary of Sweden"),^[\[25\]](#cite_note-25)^ and the [official residences](/wiki/Official_residence "Official residence") of the [Swedish monarch](/wiki/Monarchy_of_Sweden "Monarchy of Sweden") and the [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Sweden "Prime Minister of Sweden"). The government has its seat in the [Rosenbad](/wiki/Rosenbad "Rosenbad") building, the [Riksdag](/wiki/Riksdag "Riksdag") (Swedish parliament) is seated in the [Parliament House](/wiki/Parliament_House,_Stockholm "Parliament House, Stockholm"),^[\[26\]](#cite_note-26)^ and the Prime Minister's residence is adjacent at the [Sager House](/wiki/Sager_House "Sager House").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-27)^ [Stockholm Palace](/wiki/Stockholm_Palace "Stockholm Palace") is the official residence and principal workplace of the Swedish monarch, while [Drottningholm Palace](/wiki/Drottningholm_Palace "Drottningholm Palace") in neighbouring [Ekerö](/wiki/Eker%C3%B6_Municipality "Ekerö Municipality") serves as the [Royal Family](/wiki/Swedish_Royal_Family "Swedish Royal Family")'s private residence.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-28)^{#cite_ref-28}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Stockholm](/wiki/History_of_Stockholm "History of Stockholm")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Stockholm_Black_Friars%27_vault_2023_%281%29.jpg/220px-Stockholm_Black_Friars%27_vault_2023_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stockholm_Black_Friars%27_vault_2023_(1).jpg) A 14th-century vaulted cellar remains of the [Black Friars' Monastery](/wiki/Black_Friars%27_Monastery_of_Stockholm "Black Friars' Monastery of Stockholm") in the Old Town

Stockholm's location appears in [Norse sagas](/wiki/Saga "Saga") as [Agnafit](/wiki/Agnafit "Agnafit"), and in [Heimskringla](/wiki/Heimskringla "Heimskringla") in connection with the legendary king [Agne](/wiki/Agne "Agne"). [Birka](/wiki/Birka "Birka"), located near Stockholm, was one Sweden's major trade centres during the [Viking Age](/wiki/Viking_Age "Viking Age"), and its restored remains are one of [Stockholm County](/wiki/Stockholm_County "Stockholm County")'s most-visited sites.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-29)^{#cite_ref-29}

The earliest written mention of the name Stockholm dates from 1252, by which time the mines in [Bergslagen](/wiki/Bergslagen "Bergslagen") made it an important site in the iron trade. The first part of the name (*stock*) means log in Swedish, although it may also be connected to an old German word (*Stock*) meaning [fortification](/wiki/Fortification "Fortification"). The second part of the name (*holm*) means islet and is thought to refer to the islet [Helgeandsholmen](/wiki/Helgeandsholmen "Helgeandsholmen") in central Stockholm. According to *[Erik's Chronicle](/wiki/Erik%27s_Chronicle "Erik's Chronicle")* the city is said to have been founded by [Birger Jarl](/wiki/Birger_Jarl "Birger Jarl") to protect Sweden from sea invasions made by [Karelians](/wiki/Karelia_(historical_province_of_Finland) "Karelia (historical province of Finland)") after the [pillage of Sigtuna](/wiki/Sigtuna "Sigtuna") on Lake Mälaren in the summer of 1187.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-30)^{#cite_ref-30}

Stockholm's core, the present Old Town ([Gamla Stan](/wiki/Gamla_stan "Gamla stan")) was built on the central island next to Helgeandsholmen from the mid-13th century onward. The city originally rose to prominence as a result of the Baltic trade of the [Hanseatic League](/wiki/Hanseatic_League "Hanseatic League"). Stockholm developed strong economic and cultural linkages with [Lübeck](/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck "Lübeck"), [Hamburg](/wiki/Hamburg "Hamburg"), [Gdańsk](/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk "Gdańsk") (Danzig), [Visby](/wiki/Visby "Visby"), [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn") (Reval), and [Riga](/wiki/Riga "Riga") during this time.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-31)^{#cite_ref-31}

The strategic and economic importance of the city made Stockholm an important factor in relations between the rulers of the [Kalmar Union](/wiki/Kalmar_Union "Kalmar Union") and the Swedish anti-unionist movement in the fifteenth century and early sixteenth century. The Danish union monarch [Christian II](/wiki/Christian_II_of_Denmark "Christian II of Denmark") was able to enter the city in 1520 and on 8 November of that year, a massacre of opposition figures called the [Stockholm Bloodbath](/wiki/Stockholm_Bloodbath "Stockholm Bloodbath") took place and set off further uprisings that eventually led to the breakup of the Kalmar Union with the reattainment of Swedish independence. With the accession of [Gustav Vasa](/wiki/Gustav_I_of_Sweden "Gustav I of Sweden") in 1523 and the establishment of royal power, the population of Stockholm began to grow, reaching 10,000 by 1600.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-32)^{#cite_ref-32}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Suecia_1-013_%3B_Stockholm_fr%C3%A5n_%C3%B6ster-right_side_detail.jpg/220px-Suecia_1-013_%3B_Stockholm_fr%C3%A5n_%C3%B6ster-right_side_detail.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suecia_1-013_;_Stockholm_fr%C3%A5n_%C3%B6ster-right_side_detail.jpg) Detail of engraving of Stockholm from *[Suecia Antiqua et Hodierna](/wiki/Suecia_Antiqua_et_Hodierna "Suecia Antiqua et Hodierna")* by [Erik Dahlbergh](/wiki/Erik_Dahlbergh "Erik Dahlbergh") and [Willem Swidde](/wiki/Willem_Swidde "Willem Swidde"), printed in 1693

The seventeenth century saw Sweden grow into a major European power, reflected in the development of the city of Stockholm. From 1610 to 1680 the population multiplied sixfold. In 1634, Stockholm became the official capital of the Swedish empire. Trading rules were also created that gave Stockholm an essential monopoly over trade between foreign merchants and other Swedish, Baltic and [Scandinavian](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia") territories. In 1697, [Tre Kronor Castle](/wiki/Tre_Kronor_(castle) "Tre Kronor (castle)") burned down and was replaced eventually by [Stockholm Palace](/wiki/Stockholm_Palace "Stockholm Palace"); the time of the [Swedish Empire](/wiki/Swedish_Empire "Swedish Empire") also saw several architectural modernisations of the city.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-33)^{#cite_ref-33}

The beginning of the Swedish Empire saw a renaissance in the arts and sciences; the new queen, [Christina](/wiki/Christina,_Queen_of_Sweden "Christina, Queen of Sweden"), was a strong supporter of science and culture. [Réne Descartes](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes "René Descartes"), one of the most prominent European philosophers of his time, died in Stockholm; he had been hosted by the queen for several years prior to his death. Inventors, like [Christopher Polhem](/wiki/Christopher_Polhem "Christopher Polhem"), moved to the city during the time of the Swedish Empire. Academics also spent much time in Stockholm, like [Olaus Rudbeck](/wiki/Olaus_Rudbeck "Olaus Rudbeck"), rector of the [Uppsala University](/wiki/Uppsala_University "Uppsala University").^[\[34\]](#cite_note-34)^{#cite_ref-34}

Throughout Sweden's history, [walls](/wiki/Walls_of_Stockholm "Walls of Stockholm") were created in Stockholm to defend the city from attacks. These defensive walls were modified throughout the 13th to the 16th century. In 1625, the [Great Stockholm Fire of 1625](/wiki/Great_Stockholm_Fire_of_1625 "Great Stockholm Fire of 1625") destroyed the southwestern section of [Stadsholmen](/wiki/Stadsholmen "Stadsholmen"), an island in the centre of Stockholm.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-35)^ The amount of destruction led to the beginning of the demolition of the Stockholm walls. Today, most of the younger city walls cannot be found anywhere above ground. However, parts of the northern city walls are preserved in the modern [Museum of Medieval Stockholm](/wiki/Museum_of_Medieval_Stockholm "Museum of Medieval Stockholm").^[\[36\]](#cite_note-36)^{#cite_ref-36}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Map_of_Stockholm_%281713%29.tif/lossy-page1-220px-Map_of_Stockholm_%281713%29.tif.jpg)](/wiki/File:Map_of_Stockholm_(1713).tif) Map of Stockholm (1713)

In 1710, a [plague](/wiki/Plague_(disease) "Plague (disease)") [killed about 20,000](/wiki/Great_Northern_War_plague_outbreak "Great Northern War plague outbreak") (36 percent) of the population.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-37)^ After the end of the [Great Northern War](/wiki/Great_Northern_War "Great Northern War") the city stagnated; population growth halted and economic growth slowed. The city was in shock after having lost its place as the capital of a [great power](/wiki/Great_power "Great power"). However, Stockholm maintained its role as Sweden's political centre and continued to develop as the country's economic and cultural capital.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)^{#cite_ref-38}

During the [Age of Enlightenment](/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age of Enlightenment") in the late eighteenth century, the city flourished. The new monarch, [Gustav III](/wiki/Gustav_III "Gustav III"), proved an able and energetic regnant; his economic policies helped the [Swedish economy](/wiki/Economy_of_Sweden "Economy of Sweden") develop, and his partially successful [war against Russia](/wiki/Russo-Swedish_War_(1788%E2%80%931790) "Russo-Swedish War (1788–1790)") restored some of Sweden's international reputation. The king was an avid patron of the arts, and scientists and cultural figures flocked to Stockholm on a scale unprecedented since the reign of [Queen Christina](/wiki/Christina,_Queen_of_Sweden "Christina, Queen of Sweden").^[\[39\]](#cite_note-39)^{#cite_ref-39}

During this time, [Carl Michael Bellman](/wiki/Carl_Michael_Bellman "Carl Michael Bellman") and [Joseph Martin Kraus](/wiki/Joseph_Martin_Kraus "Joseph Martin Kraus") helped develop the city's music, a process further accelerated by the founding of the [Royal Swedish Opera](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Opera "Royal Swedish Opera").^[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)^ Various artists and writers became prominent, funded by the king and other cultural patrons like [Carl Gustaf Tessin](/wiki/Carl_Gustaf_Tessin "Carl Gustaf Tessin"); the two aforementioned figures laid the base for Sweden's [Nationalmuseum](/wiki/Nationalmuseum "Nationalmuseum") at this time. Science also became prevalent; renowned figures like [Carl Linnaeus](/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus "Carl Linnaeus") and [Anders Celsius](/wiki/Anders_Celsius "Anders Celsius") spent time in Stockholm, and various research institutes, like the [Stockholm Observatory](/wiki/Stockholm_Observatory "Stockholm Observatory"), were founded.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Stockholm_panorama_1868.jpg/220px-Stockholm_panorama_1868.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stockholm_panorama_1868.jpg) Panorama over Stockholm c. 1868 as seen from a [hot air balloon](/wiki/Hot_air_balloon "Hot air balloon")

The early nineteenth century saw a major economic decline of Stockholm and Sweden as a whole, but by the second half of the nineteenth century, Stockholm had regained its leading economic role. New industries emerged with industrialisation and Stockholm was transformed into an important trade and service centre as well as a key gateway point within Sweden. The population also grew dramatically during this time, mainly through [immigration](/wiki/Immigration "Immigration"). At the end of the nineteenth century, less than 40% of the residents were Stockholm-born, with most migrants being from poorer rural Sweden; major settlement began to expand outside the historical city limits. The nineteenth century also saw the establishment of a number of scientific institutes and universities, including the [Karolinska Institutet](/wiki/Karolinska_Institutet "Karolinska Institutet") and [KTH Royal Institute of Technology](/wiki/KTH_Royal_Institute_of_Technology "KTH Royal Institute of Technology"). The [General Art and Industrial Exposition](/wiki/General_Art_and_Industrial_Exposition_of_Stockholm_(1897) "General Art and Industrial Exposition of Stockholm (1897)") was held in 1897,^[\[42\]](#cite_note-42)^ drawing international attention. From 1887 to 1953 the [Old Stockholm telephone tower](/wiki/Old_Stockholm_telephone_tower "Old Stockholm telephone tower") was a landmark; originally built to link phone lines, it became redundant after these were buried, and it was later used for advertising before its demolition in the twentieth century. The early twentieth century also saw the creation of the [Nobel Prizes](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize"), some of Stockholm's most renowned institutions.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-43)^{#cite_ref-43}

Stockholm became a modern and ethnically diverse city in the latter half of the 20th century. Many historical buildings were torn down during the [modernist](/wiki/Modernism "Modernism") era, including substantial parts of the historical district of [Klara](/wiki/Klara_(Stockholm) "Klara (Stockholm)") (which caused major controversy), and replaced with modern architecture. However, in many other parts of Stockholm (such as in [Gamla stan](/wiki/Gamla_stan "Gamla stan"), [Södermalm](/wiki/S%C3%B6dermalm "Södermalm"), [Östermalm](/wiki/%C3%96stermalm "Östermalm"), [Kungsholmen](/wiki/Kungsholmen "Kungsholmen") and [Vasastan](/wiki/Vasastan,_Stockholm "Vasastan, Stockholm")), many older buildings, blocks and streets built before the modernism and [functionalism](/wiki/Functionalism_(architecture) "Functionalism (architecture)") movements survived this era of demolition. Throughout the century, many industries shifted away from industrial activities into more high-tech and service industry areas, which still dominate the city's economy today.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-eurocompanyformations.com-21)^{#cite_ref-eurocompanyformations.com_21-1}

Stockholm's metropolitan area has become one of the fastest-growing regions in Europe.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ In 2020 alone, Stockholm's population increased by 1,477.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-44)^ As a result of this massive population growth, there has been a proposal to build densely packed high-rise buildings in the city centre connected by elevated walkways, though these have been opposed by several groups.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Geography")\]  
Main article: [Geography of Stockholm](/wiki/Geography_of_Stockholm "Geography of Stockholm")  

### Location {#Location}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Location")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Stockholm_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2018-07-16.jpg/220px-Stockholm_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2018-07-16.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stockholm_by_Sentinel-2,_2018-07-16.jpg) Satellite image of Stockholm in 2018 by ESA

Stockholm is located on Sweden's east coast at the 59th parallel north,^[\[46\]](#cite_note-Nord59.se-46)^ where the freshwater [Lake Mälaren](/wiki/Lake_M%C3%A4laren "Lake Mälaren")---Sweden's third-largest lake---flows out into the Baltic Sea. The central parts of the city consist of fourteen islands that are continuous with the [Stockholm archipelago](/wiki/Stockholm_archipelago "Stockholm archipelago"). The geographical city centre is situated on the water, in [Riddarfjärden](/wiki/Riddarfj%C3%A4rden "Riddarfjärden") bay. Over 30% of the city area is made up of waterways and another 30% is made up of parks and green spaces.{#cite_ref-Nord59.se_46-0}

Positioned at the eastern end of the [Central Swedish lowland](/wiki/Central_Swedish_lowland "Central Swedish lowland") and near the [Bergslagen](/wiki/Bergslagen "Bergslagen") region, the city's location reflects the early orientation of Swedish trade toward the Baltic region.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-Worldregional-47)^{#cite_ref-Worldregional_47-0}

Stockholm belongs to the [Temperate deciduous forest](/wiki/Temperate_deciduous_forest "Temperate deciduous forest") biome, which means the climate is very similar to that of the far northeastern area of the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") and coastal [Nova Scotia](/wiki/Nova_Scotia "Nova Scotia") in [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"). The average annual temperature is 7.9 °C (46 °F). The average rainfall is 531 mm (21 in) per year. The deciduous forest has four distinct seasons, spring, summer, autumn, and winter. In the autumn the leaves change color. During the winter months, the trees lose their leaves.^\[*[excessive detail?](/wiki/Wikipedia:TERSE "Wikipedia:TERSE")*\]^

For details about the other municipalities in the Stockholm area, see the pertinent articles. ### Stockholm Municipality {#Stockholm_Municipality}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Stockholm Municipality")\]  
Main article: [Stockholm Municipality](/wiki/Stockholm_Municipality "Stockholm Municipality")

Stockholm Municipality is an administrative unit defined by geographical borders. The semi-official name for the municipality is *City of Stockholm* (*Stockholms stad* in Swedish).^[\[48\]](#cite_note-48)^ As a municipality, the City of Stockholm is subdivided into district councils, which carry responsibility for primary schools, social, leisure and cultural services within their respective areas. The municipality is usually described in terms of its three main parts: Innerstaden ([Stockholm City Centre](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Centre "Stockholm City Centre")), [Söderort](/wiki/S%C3%B6derort "Söderort") (Southern Stockholm) and [Västerort](/wiki/V%C3%A4sterort "Västerort") (Western Stockholm). The districts of these parts are:{#cite_ref-48}

The modern centre [Norrmalm](/wiki/Norrmalm_(proper) "Norrmalm (proper)") (concentrated around the town square [Sergels torg](/wiki/Sergels_torg "Sergels torg")) is the largest shopping district in [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden").^[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)^ It is the most central part of Stockholm in business and shopping.{#cite_ref-49}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Stockholm has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") in the 0 °C isotherm ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Dfb* )^[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)^^[\[51\]](#cite_note-51)^ bordering on an [oceanic climate](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") (*Cfb* ) in the -3 °C isotherm. Although winters are cold, average temperatures generally remain above 0 °C for much of the year. Summers are pleasantly warm, and precipitation occurs throughout the year.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-52)^{#cite_ref-52}

Due to the city's high northerly latitude, the length of the day varies widely from more than 18 hours around midsummer to only around 6 hours in late December. The nights from late May until mid-July are not completely dark even when cloudy. Stockholm has relatively mild weather compared to other locations at a similar latitude, or even farther south. With an average of 1900 hours of sunshine per year, it is also one of the sunniest cities in Northern Europe, receiving more sunshine than Paris, London and a few other major European cities of a more southerly latitude. Because of the [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effect and the prevailing wind travelling overland rather than sea during summer months, Stockholm has the warmest July months of the Nordic capitals. Stockholm has an annual average snow cover between 75 and 100 days.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}

Despite its mild climate, Stockholm is located further north than parts of Canada that are above the Arctic [tree line](/wiki/Tree_line "Tree line") at sea level.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-54)^{#cite_ref-54}

Summers average daytime high temperatures of 20--25 °C (68--77 °F) and lows of around 13 °C (55 °F), but temperatures can reach 30 °C (86 °F) on some days. Days above 30 °C (86 °F) occur on average 1.55 days per year (1992--2011).^[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)^ Days between 25 °C (77 °F) and 30 °C (86 °F) are relatively common especially in July and August. Night-time lows of above 20 °C (68 °F) are rare, and hot summer nights vary from 17 to 18 °C (63 to 64 °F). Winters generally bring cloudy weather with the most precipitation falling in December and January (as either rain or snow). The average winter temperatures range from −3 to −1 °C (27 to 30 °F), and occasionally drop below −20 °C (−4 °F) in the outskirts of the city. Spring and autumn are generally cool to mild.{#cite_ref-55}

The climate table below presents weather data from the years 1991--2020. According to ongoing measurements, the temperature has increased during the years 1991--2020 as compared with the last series, from 1961 to 1990. This increase averages about 1.0 °C (1.8 °F) over all months. Warming is most pronounced during the winter months, with an increase of more than 2.0 °C (3.6 °F) in January.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-56)^ For the 2002--2014 measurements some further increases have been found, although some months such as June have been relatively flat.{#cite_ref-56}

The highest temperature ever recorded in Stockholm was 36 °C (97 °F) on 3 July 1811; the lowest was −32 °C (−26 °F) on 20 January 1814.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-57)^ The temperature has not dropped to below −25.1 °C (−13.2 °F) since 10 January 1987.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-58)^^[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)^{#cite_ref-59}

The warmest month ever recorded was July 2018 with a mean temperature of 22.5 °C (72.5 °F) which is also the nationwide record.

Annual precipitation is 546.4 mm (21.51 in) with around 170 wet days and light to moderate rainfall throughout the year. The precipitation is not uniformly distributed throughout the year. The second half of the year receives 50% more than the first half. Snowfall occurs mainly from December through March. Snowfall may occasionally occur in late October as well as in April.

In Stockholm, the [aurora borealis](/wiki/Aurora_borealis "Aurora borealis") can occasionally be observed.

### Daylight {#Daylight}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Daylight")\]

Stockholm's location just south of the 60th parallel north means that the number of daylight hours is relatively small during winter -- about six hours -- while in June and the first half of July, the nights are relatively short, with about 18 hours of daylight. Due to its eastern position within Sweden's respective time zone, sunsets occur as early as 2:46 PM in mid-December. Around the [summer solstice](/wiki/Summer_solstice "Summer solstice") the sun never reaches further below the [horizon](/wiki/Horizon "Horizon") than 7.3 degrees.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-67)^ This gives the sky a bright blue colour in summer once the sun has set because it does not get any darker than [nautical twilight](/wiki/Nautical_twilight "Nautical twilight"). Also, when looking straight up towards the [zenith](/wiki/Zenith "Zenith"), few stars are visible after the sun has gone down. This is not to be confused with the [midnight sun](/wiki/Midnight_sun "Midnight sun"), which occurs north of the [Arctic Circle](/wiki/Arctic_Circle "Arctic Circle"), around 7 degrees farther north.{#cite_ref-67}  

Government {#Government}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Government")\]  
See also: [Stockholm Municipality](/wiki/Stockholm_Municipality "Stockholm Municipality")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/5c2_The_council_hall_in_stockholm_city_hall_-_r%C3%A5dssalen.JPG/220px-5c2_The_council_hall_in_stockholm_city_hall_-_r%C3%A5dssalen.JPG)](/wiki/File:5c2_The_council_hall_in_stockholm_city_hall_-_r%C3%A5dssalen.JPG) The municipal council chamber ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Rådssalen* ), inside [Stockholm City Hall](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Hall "Stockholm City Hall")

The Stockholm [Municipal Council](/wiki/Municipal_council_(Sweden) "Municipal council (Sweden)") ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Stockholms kommunfullmäktige* ) is the name of the local assembly. Its 101 councillors are elected concurrently with [general elections](/wiki/Elections_in_Sweden "Elections in Sweden"), held at the same time as the elections to the [Riksdag](/wiki/Riksdag "Riksdag") and [county councils](/wiki/County_councils_of_Sweden "County councils of Sweden"). The Council convenes twice every month at [Stockholm City Hall](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Hall "Stockholm City Hall"), and the meetings are open to the public. The matters on which the councillors decide have generally already been drafted and discussed by various boards and committees. Once decisions are referred for practical implementation, the employees of the City administrations and companies take over.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-Governance-68)^{#cite_ref-Governance_68-0}

The elected majority has a Mayor and eight Vice Mayors. The Mayor and each majority Vice Mayor is the head of a department, with responsibility for a particular area of operation, such as City Planning. The opposition also has four Vice Mayors, but they hold no executive power. Together the Mayor and the 12 Vice Mayors form the Council of Mayors, and they prepare matters for the City Executive Board. The Mayor holds a special position among the Vice Mayors, chairing both the Council of Mayors and the City Executive Board.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-Governance-68)^{#cite_ref-Governance_68-1}

The City Executive Board ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *[Kommunstyrelsen](/w/index.php?title=Kommunstyrelsen&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kommunstyrelsen (page does not exist)")* ) is elected by the City Council and is equivalent to a [cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_(government) "Cabinet (government)"). The City Executive Board renders an opinion in all matters decided by the council and bears the overall responsibility for follow-up, evaluation and execution of its decisions. The Board is also responsible for financial administration and long-term development. The City Executive Board consists of 13 members, who represent both the majority and the opposition. Its meetings are not open to the public.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-Governance-68)^{#cite_ref-Governance_68-2}

[Stockholm City Hall](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Hall "Stockholm City Hall") is one of the city's key landmarks, built in the [National Romantic Style](/wiki/National_Romantic_style "National Romantic style") at the beginning of the twentieth century. Hosting the Nobel Prizes and the government of the city of Stockholm, it is one of Sweden's most important buildings.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-69)^{#cite_ref-69}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Kistavictoriahotelnr1_Publish.jpg/220px-Kistavictoriahotelnr1_Publish.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kistavictoriahotelnr1_Publish.jpg) Victoria Tower is one of the tallest buildings in Stockholm, located in [Kista](/wiki/Kista "Kista"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Isafjord_1_October_2015_01.jpg/220px-Isafjord_1_October_2015_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Isafjord_1_October_2015_01.jpg) Headquarters of [Ericsson](/wiki/Ericsson "Ericsson")  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Economy")\]

As the primary financial centre in Sweden, Stockholm is an influential hub for trade, finance and technology in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), and one of Scandinavia's largest financial centres. The Stockholm region is the leading region in Sweden by both GDP and GDP per capita, and is amongst the ten wealthiest regions in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") when measured by the latter.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-70)^{#cite_ref-70}

Many of Sweden's largest companies are headquartered in the city; they are drawn by its central location, skilled workforce and preeminent financial sector. These companies include some of the [Nordic region](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries")'s most valuable corporations, like [Ericsson](/wiki/Ericsson "Ericsson"), which is one of the world's largest telecommunications companies, or [Atlas Copco](/wiki/Atlas_Copco "Atlas Copco"), which is one of the world's largest industrial companies; other large companies based in Stockholm include [Electrolux](/wiki/Electrolux "Electrolux"), [H\&M](/wiki/H%26M "H&M") and [Securitas AB](/wiki/Securitas_AB "Securitas AB"). Some of the largest investment firms in Europe are headquartered in the city, including [Investor AB](/wiki/Investor_AB "Investor AB") and [Nordstjernan](/wiki/Nordstjernan "Nordstjernan"); also headquartered in Stockholm is [EQT AB](/wiki/EQT_AB "EQT AB").^[\[71\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}

Stockholm is one of continental Europe's leading hubs for the technology industry; this influential industry is based in [Kista](/wiki/Kista "Kista"), a suburb in northern Stockholm which is Europe's largest Informations and Technology cluster. Stockholm has the second most unicorns per capita in the world, after Silicon Valley; the city also has one of the highest startup rates in Europe.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-72)^ Prominent startup technology companies in Stockholm include [Mojang](/wiki/Mojang_Studios "Mojang Studios"), [Spotify](/wiki/Spotify "Spotify") and [Klarna](/wiki/Klarna "Klarna"); the latter two either have been or are among the largest startup companies in the world.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-73)^{#cite_ref-73}

Most of Sweden's largest banks are headquartered in the city, including the [SEB Group](/wiki/SEB_Group "SEB Group"), [Handelsbanken](/wiki/Handelsbanken "Handelsbanken") and [Swedbank](/wiki/Swedbank "Swedbank"); [Nordea](/wiki/Nordea "Nordea") had its headquarters in Stockholm until moving to [Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki") in 2018 for legal reasons involving the European Union.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-74)^ The [Stockholm Stock Exchange](/wiki/Nasdaq_Stockholm "Nasdaq Stockholm"), founded in 1863, is the largest stock exchange in the Nordic Countries measured by market capitalisation, listing numerous multinational Swedish companies.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-75)^{#cite_ref-75}

Trade is a vital part of Stockholm's economy; the city's corporations are largely reliant on foreign consumers to supplement the small Swedish market. Stockholm is one of the Baltic Sea's larger ports, hosting especially cruise ships and yachts. Most of Stockholm's economy is based on export-oriented services, often towards larger, nearby European markets like Poland or Germany.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-76)^ Tourism is a major industry in Stockholm.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-77)^{#cite_ref-77}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Education")\]  
Main article: [Education in Stockholm](/wiki/Education_in_Stockholm "Education in Stockholm")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Karolinska_Institute.jpg/220px-Karolinska_Institute.jpg)](/wiki/File:Karolinska_Institute.jpg) [Karolinska Institute](/wiki/Karolinska_Institute "Karolinska Institute"), Sweden's third oldest medical school and one of the foremost medical research institution globally. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/KTH_entrance.jpg/220px-KTH_entrance.jpg)](/wiki/File:KTH_entrance.jpg) [KTH Royal Institute of Technology](/wiki/KTH_Royal_Institute_of_Technology "KTH Royal Institute of Technology"), the largest technical institution in Sweden mainly focuses on conducting research and providing education in engineering, science and technology.

Research and higher education in the sciences started in Stockholm in the 18th century, with education in medicine and various research institutions such as the [Stockholm Observatory](/wiki/Stockholm_Observatory "Stockholm Observatory"). The medical education was eventually formalised in 1811 as [Karolinska Institutet](/wiki/Karolinska_Institute "Karolinska Institute"). [KTH Royal Institute of Technology](/wiki/KTH_Royal_Institute_of_Technology "KTH Royal Institute of Technology") (*Swedish: Kungliga Tekniska högskolan* ) was founded in 1827 and is Scandinavia's largest higher education institute of technology with 13,000 students; it is Sweden's foremost polytechnic, and spearheaded several governmental research projects in the twentieth century. [Stockholm University](/wiki/Stockholm_University "Stockholm University"), founded in 1878 with university status granted in 1960, has 52,000 students as of 2008^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit)^. It also incorporates historical institutions, such as the Observatory, the [Swedish Museum of Natural History](/wiki/Swedish_Museum_of_Natural_History "Swedish Museum of Natural History"), as well as the botanical garden *[Bergianska trädgården](/wiki/Bergianska_tr%C3%A4dg%C3%A5rden "Bergianska trädgården")* . The [Stockholm School of Economics](/wiki/Stockholm_School_of_Economics "Stockholm School of Economics"), founded in 1909, is one of the few private institutions of higher education in Sweden, and is generally reckoned one of the most prestigious business schools in the world.

In the [fine arts](/wiki/Fine_art "Fine art"), educational institutions include the [Royal College of Music](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music,_Stockholm "Royal College of Music, Stockholm"), which has a history going back to the conservatory founded as part of the [Royal Swedish Academy of Music](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Academy_of_Music "Royal Swedish Academy of Music") in 1771, the [Royal University College of Fine Arts](/wiki/Royal_Institute_of_Art "Royal Institute of Art"), which has a similar historical association with the [Royal Swedish Academy of Arts](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Academy_of_Arts "Royal Swedish Academy of Arts") and a foundation date of 1735, and the [Swedish National Academy of Mime and Acting](/wiki/Swedish_National_Academy_of_Mime_and_Acting "Swedish National Academy of Mime and Acting"), which is the continuation of the school of the [Royal Dramatic Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Dramatic_Theatre "Royal Dramatic Theatre"), once attended by renowned actors like [Greta Garbo](/wiki/Greta_Garbo "Greta Garbo"). Other schools include the design school [Konstfack](/wiki/Konstfack "Konstfack"), founded in 1844, the [University College of Opera](/wiki/University_College_of_Opera "University College of Opera") (founded in 1968 but with older roots), the [University College of Dance](/wiki/University_of_Dance_and_Circus "University of Dance and Circus"), and the *[Stockholms Musikpedagogiska Institut](/wiki/Stockholms_Musikpedagogiska_Institut "Stockholms Musikpedagogiska Institut")* (the University College of Music Education).

The [Södertörn University](/wiki/S%C3%B6dert%C3%B6rn_University "Södertörn University") was founded in 1995 as a multi-disciplinary institution for southern [Metropolitan Stockholm](/wiki/Metropolitan_Stockholm "Metropolitan Stockholm"), to balance the many institutions located in the northern part of the region. Other institutes of higher education include the [Military Academy Karlberg](/wiki/Military_Academy_Karlberg "Military Academy Karlberg"), the world's oldest military academy to remain in its original location, inaugurated in 1792 and housed in [Karlberg Palace](/wiki/Karlberg_Palace "Karlberg Palace"); there is also the [Swedish Defence University](/wiki/Swedish_Defence_University "Swedish Defence University"), [Ersta Sköndal University College](/wiki/Ersta_Sk%C3%B6ndal_University_College "Ersta Sköndal University College"), [Swedish School of Sport and Health Sciences](/wiki/Swedish_School_of_Sport_and_Health_Sciences "Swedish School of Sport and Health Sciences") and the [University College Stockholm](/wiki/University_College_Stockholm "University College Stockholm").^[\[78\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}

The biggest complaints from students of higher education in Stockholm are the lack of student accommodations, the difficulty in finding other accommodations and the high rent.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}

The Stockholm region is home to around 22% of Sweden's total population, and accounts for about 29% of its [gross domestic product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product").^[\[80\]](#cite_note-80)^ The geographical notion of "Stockholm" has changed over time. By the turn of the 19th century, Stockholm largely consisted of the area today known as City Centre, roughly 35 km^2^ (14 sq mi) or one-fifth of the current municipal area. In the ensuing decades several other areas were incorporated (such as [Brännkyrka](/wiki/Br%C3%A4nnkyrka "Brännkyrka") Municipality in 1913, at which time it had 25,000 inhabitants, and [Spånga](/wiki/Sp%C3%A5nga "Spånga") in 1949). The municipal border was established in 1971; with the exception of Hansta, in 1982 purchased by Stockholm Municipality from Sollentuna Municipality and today a nature reserve.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-SthlmStatistic2006-81)^{#cite_ref-SthlmStatistic2006_81-0}

The population was 984,748 in 2022 and is projected to reach 1,079,213 by 2030. Of the inhabitants, 482,982 were men and 492,569 women. The average age is 39 years; 40.1% of the population is between 20 and 44 years. The marimonial statistics are that 411,273 people, or 42.2% of the population, over the age 15 were unmarried; 268,291 people, or 27.5% of the population, were married; and 104,099 or 10.7% of the population, had been married but divorced.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-arsbok_2022-83)^{#cite_ref-arsbok_2022_83-0}

As of December 2021, there were 252,750 foreign-born people in Stockholm, making up 25.8% of the population. Around 57.5% of them (143,167) immigrated to Sweden when they were at least 10 years old, and 109,213 (43.9%) of them were foreign citizens. The largest nationality groups among the foreign-born people were the [Iraqis](/wiki/Iraqis "Iraqis") (16,137), followed by [Finns](/wiki/Finns "Finns") (15,693), Iranians (12,329) and [Poles](/wiki/Polish_people "Polish people") (11,569). Of the population, 336,275 residents (34.4%) of Stockholm had a foreign-background.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}

Residents of Stockholm are known as Stockholmers ("*stockholmare* "). Languages spoken in Greater Stockholm outside of Swedish include Finnish, one of the [official minority languages of Sweden](/wiki/Official_minority_languages_of_Sweden "Official minority languages of Sweden"); and English, as well as [Albanian](/wiki/Albanian_language "Albanian language"), [Bosnian language](/wiki/Bosnian_language "Bosnian language"), [Neo-Aramaic](/wiki/Neo-Aramaic "Neo-Aramaic") ([Sureth](/wiki/Sureth "Sureth")/[Turoyo](/wiki/Turoyo "Turoyo")), [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"), [Turkish](/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language"), [Kurdish](/wiki/Kurdish_language "Kurdish language"), [Farsi](/wiki/Farsi "Farsi"), [Somali](/wiki/Somali_language "Somali language"), [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language"), [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"), [Serbian](/wiki/Serbian_language "Serbian language") and [Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language "Croatian language").

Stockholm has been home to a significant [Finnish-minority](/wiki/Sweden_Finns "Sweden Finns") since the 13th century. At the end of the 15th century up to 20% of the population in Stockholm consisted of Finns.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-85)^ The [Finska församlingen](/w/index.php?title=Finska_f%C3%B6rsamlingen&action=edit&redlink=1 "Finska församlingen (page does not exist)") \[[sv](https://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finska_f%C3%B6rsamlingen "sv:Finska församlingen")\] has offered church services since the 16th century, and in 1725 the [Finnish Church](/wiki/Finnish_Church,_Stockholm "Finnish Church, Stockholm") was opened. 74,000 people in Stockholm have a Finnish-background, which makes Stockholm home to the largest Finnish population in Sweden.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-86)^ [Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language"), along with [Meänkieli](/wiki/Me%C3%A4nkieli "Meänkieli") and the [Sami languages](/wiki/Sami_languages "Sami languages") have a protected minority status in Stockholm. This gives the right to use their language when contacting authorities, as well as the right to child and elderly care in their languages. [Romani chib](/wiki/Romani_language "Romani language") and [Yiddish](/wiki/Yiddish "Yiddish") are also recognized minority languages, and have a strengthened right to their language in education.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-87)^{#cite_ref-87}

The entire [Stockholm metropolitan area](/wiki/Stockholm_metropolitan_area "Stockholm metropolitan area"), consisting of 26 municipalities, has a population of over 2.2 million,^[\[88\]](#cite_note-scb2-88)^ making it the most populous region in the [Nordic countries](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries").^[\[89\]](#cite_note-nordic-89)^ The [Stockholm urban area](/wiki/Stockholm_urban_area "Stockholm urban area"), defined only for statistical purposes, had a total population of 1,630,738 in 2015. In the following [municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Sweden "Municipalities of Sweden") some of the districts are contained within the Stockholm urban area, though not all:^[\[6\]](#cite_note-ne-6)^^[\[7\]](#cite_note-StockholmUrbanArea-7)^{#cite_ref-StockholmUrbanArea_7-1}
