### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Religion")\]

The Swedish church consists of [27 parishes in Stockholm](/wiki/Diocese_of_Stockholm_(Church_of_Sweden) "Diocese of Stockholm (Church of Sweden)") with almost 50 churches, but also a large number of churches belonging to the free church.

Stockholm has six mosques.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-NAME1-91)^{#cite_ref-NAME1_91-0}

There are three active synagogues and a community of 4,300 members in Stockholm, which corresponds to 0.4% of Stockholm's population.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-NAME2-92)^ It is the largest Jewish community in [Scandinavia](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia").{#cite_ref-NAME2_92-0}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Culture")\]  
Main article: [Culture in Stockholm](/wiki/Culture_in_Stockholm "Culture in Stockholm")

As the capital and largest city of Sweden, Stockholm is the primary centre for the country's cultural life. The [Swedish Royal Academies](/wiki/Swedish_Royal_Academies "Swedish Royal Academies"), founded by various monarchs after the sixteenth century, award several prestigious awards and serve as intellectual institutions for the country's leading figures. The city also hosts several of Sweden's architectural masterpieces; the Stockholm region is home to three [World Heritage Sites](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") -- spots judged as invaluable places that belong to all of humanity: The [Drottningholm Palace](/wiki/Drottningholm_Palace "Drottningholm Palace"), [Skogskyrkogården](/wiki/Skogskyrkog%C3%A5rden "Skogskyrkogården") (The Woodland Cemetery) and [Birka](/wiki/Birka "Birka").^[\[93\]](#cite_note-Drottningholm-93)^^[\[94\]](#cite_note-94)^^[\[95\]](#cite_note-Skogskyrkogården-95)^ In 1998, Stockholm was named [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture").{#cite_ref-Skogskyrkogården_95-0}  

### Literature {#Literature}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Literature")\]

Since its founding, Stockholm has been home to many authors of worldwide recognition; these include figures like [August Strindberg](/wiki/August_Strindberg "August Strindberg") and [Astrid Lindgren](/wiki/Astrid_Lindgren "Astrid Lindgren"), as well as other writers important to the development of Swedish literature, like [Vilhelm Moberg](/wiki/Vilhelm_Moberg "Vilhelm Moberg") or [Olof von Dalin](/wiki/Olof_von_Dalin "Olof von Dalin"). Stockholm has an active literary life, as it hosts two of Europe's most important literary institutions: the [Swedish Academy](/wiki/Swedish_Academy "Swedish Academy") and [National Library of Sweden](/wiki/National_Library_of_Sweden "National Library of Sweden").^[\[96\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

Literature in Stockholm began during the Viking Age, when numerous runestones were carved in the area due to its importance as a trading hub. However, Sweden's literature at the time was primarily based in [Götaland](/wiki/G%C3%B6taland "Götaland") and [Uppsala](/wiki/Uppsala "Uppsala"), as evidenced by the abundance of runestones in these areas and the settings of poems like [Beowulf](/wiki/Beowulf "Beowulf"). The presence of the [Church](/wiki/Church_of_Sweden "Church of Sweden") and [University](/wiki/Uppsala_University "Uppsala University") only served to further strengthen Uppsala's role as Sweden's literary centre throughout Christianisation and the Middle Ages.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}

The centralisation of royal power and relative secularism brought in the sixteenth century led to the rise of Stockholm in Sweden's literature; this is due to several factors, including royal patronage in Stockholm and the relative decline of Uppsala University. The Bible was translated into Swedish during the reign of [Gustav Vasa](/wiki/Gustav_I_of_Sweden "Gustav I of Sweden"), and he drew several writers to his court due to his fondness for both music and literature.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-98)^{#cite_ref-98}

Stockholm's literature first began to flourish in the seventeenth century, with notable writers from the rest of Sweden moving to the city due to the wealth and patronage born from the spoils of the [Swedish Empire](/wiki/Swedish_Empire "Swedish Empire"). This process of cultural advancement continued into the eighteenth century, where the Gustavian era brought Stockholm's literature to its peak. [Carl Linnaeus](/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus "Carl Linnaeus")'s scientific works were influential literary pieces, with August Strindberg describing Linnaeus as a "poet who happened to become a naturalist". Another notable literary figure from this time is [Carl Michael Bellman](/wiki/Carl_Michael_Bellman "Carl Michael Bellman"), with his unique gift for setting his poems to song; he is often considered the father of the Swedish ballad tradition.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}

The nineteenth and twentieth centuries were also a good time for the literature of Stockholm, with the rise of the [Romantic](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism") and [Realist](/wiki/Literary_realism "Literary realism") movements, respectively. August Strindberg rose to prominence in the late nineteenth century with several important works; he is still considered one of Sweden's finest writers. Astrid Lindgren, in the twentieth century, was famous for her children's stories, while Vilhelm Moberg's works are often considered national treasures in Sweden.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-100)^^[\[101\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Architecture")\]  
Main article: [Architecture in Stockholm](/wiki/Architecture_in_Stockholm "Architecture in Stockholm")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Stockholm_Port.jpg/220px-Stockholm_Port.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stockholm_Port.jpg) Strandvägen as seen from the island of [Djurgården](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rden "Djurgården") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Djurgardsbron_2008.jpg/220px-Djurgardsbron_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Djurgardsbron_2008.jpg) [Djurgårdsbron](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rdsbron "Djurgårdsbron") bridge from the large island which is still under [direct royal control](/wiki/Royal_Right_of_Disposal_(Sweden) "Royal Right of Disposal (Sweden)") since the 18th century [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Stockholms-stadsbibliotek-2003-04-14.jpg/220px-Stockholms-stadsbibliotek-2003-04-14.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stockholms-stadsbibliotek-2003-04-14.jpg) [Stockholm Public Library](/wiki/Stockholm_Public_Library "Stockholm Public Library"), designed by architect [Gunnar Asplund](/wiki/Gunnar_Asplund "Gunnar Asplund")

Stockholm's oldest section is Gamla Stan (Old Town), located on the original small islands of the city's earliest settlements and still featuring the [medieval](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages") street layout. Some notable buildings of Gamla Stan are the large [German Church](/wiki/German_Church,_Stockholm "German Church, Stockholm") (*Tyska kyrkan* ) and several mansions and palaces: the *[Riddarhuset](/wiki/Swedish_House_of_Nobility "Swedish House of Nobility")* (the House of Nobility), the [Bonde Palace](/wiki/Bonde_Palace "Bonde Palace"), the [Tessin Palace](/wiki/Tessin_Palace "Tessin Palace") and the [Oxenstierna Palace](/wiki/Axel_Oxenstierna_palace "Axel Oxenstierna palace").

The oldest building in Stockholm is [Riddarholmen Church](/wiki/Riddarholmen_Church "Riddarholmen Church") from the late 13th century. After a fire in 1697 when the original medieval castle was destroyed, [Stockholm Palace](/wiki/Stockholm_Palace "Stockholm Palace") was erected in a [baroque](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") style. [Storkyrkan](/wiki/Storkyrkan "Storkyrkan") Cathedral, the episcopal seat of the Bishop of Stockholm, stands next to the castle. It was founded in the 13th century but is clad in a baroque exterior dating to the 1730-40s.

As early as the 15th century, the city had expanded outside of its original borders. Some pre-industrial, small-scale buildings from this era can still be found in [Södermalm](/wiki/S%C3%B6dermalm "Södermalm"). Norrmalm, now the central part of the shopping district of Stockholm, was originally a separate city but was incorporated in Stockholm (now Old Town) during the early 17th century.

Stockholm has had a tradition of applying for building permits in order to erect a building from the early 18th century, with the oldest building permit from 1713. The building permit application tradition is still ongoing; as a consequence, it is possible to trace the continuous history of a newly built house three centuries into the past. Today the Stockholm City Building committee is in charge of the building permit process and their 1713--1978 archive is maintained by [Stockholm City Archives](https://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stockholms_stadsarkiv "sv:Stockholms stadsarkiv"). All drawings of old buildings from 1713 to 1874 are digitised and available through the Stockholms City Archives' website.

At the age of industrialisation and at the end of the 19th century and Stockholm grew rapidly, with plans and architecture inspired by the large cities of the continent such as [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin") and [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"). Notable works of this time period include public buildings such as the [Royal Swedish Opera](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Opera "Royal Swedish Opera") and private developments such as the luxury housing developments on [Strandvägen](/wiki/Strandv%C3%A4gen "Strandvägen").

In the 20th century, a nationalistic push spurred a new architectural style inspired by medieval and renaissance ancestry as well as influences of the [Jugend](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau")/Art Nouveau style. A key landmark of Stockholm, the Stockholm City Hall, was erected 1911--1923 by architect [Ragnar Östberg](/wiki/Ragnar_%C3%96stberg "Ragnar Östberg"). Other notable works of these times are the [Stockholm Public Library](/wiki/Stockholm_Public_Library "Stockholm Public Library") by [Gunnar Asplund](/wiki/Gunnar_Asplund "Gunnar Asplund") and the [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") [Skogskyrkogården](/wiki/Skogskyrkog%C3%A5rden "Skogskyrkogården") by [Asplund](/wiki/Gunnar_Asplund "Gunnar Asplund") and celebrated architect [Sigurd Lewerentz](/wiki/Sigurd_Lewerentz "Sigurd Lewerentz").^[\[95\]](#cite_note-Skogskyrkogården-95)^{#cite_ref-Skogskyrkogården_95-1}

In the 1930s modernism characterised the development of the city as it grew. New residential areas sprang up such as the development on [Gärdet](/wiki/G%C3%A4rdet "Gärdet") while industrial development added to the growth, such as the KF manufacturing industries on Kvarnholmen located in the Nacka Municipality. In the 1950s, suburban development entered a new phase, that had already started in the early 1930s, with the introduction of the [Stockholm metro](/wiki/Stockholm_metro "Stockholm metro"). The modernist developments of [Vällingby](/wiki/V%C3%A4llingby "Vällingby") and [Farsta](/wiki/Farsta "Farsta") were internationally praised. In the 1960s this suburban development continued but with the aesthetic of the times, the industrialised and mass-produced blocks of flats received considerable criticism.

At the same time that this suburban development was taking place, the most central areas of the inner city were being redesigned, known as *[Norrmalmsregleringen](/wiki/Redevelopment_of_Norrmalm "Redevelopment of Norrmalm")* . [Sergels Torg](/wiki/Sergels_Torg "Sergels Torg"), with its five high-rise office towers was created in the 1960s, followed by the total clearance of large areas to make room for new development projects. The most notable buildings from this period include the ensemble of the [House of Culture](/wiki/The_House_of_Culture_(Stockholm) "The House of Culture (Stockholm)"), [City Theatre](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Theatre "Stockholm City Theatre") and the [Riksbank](/wiki/Sveriges_Riksbank "Sveriges Riksbank") at Sergels Torg, designed by architect [Peter Celsing](/wiki/Peter_Celsing "Peter Celsing"). Other celebrated works from the 1960s was [S:t Görans Gymnasium](https://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/S:t_G%C3%B6rans_gymnasium "sv:S:t Görans gymnasium") (originally built as a school for women, the School of House work and Sewing) by [Leonie Geisendorf](/wiki/L%C3%A9onie_Geisendorf "Léonie Geisendorf").

The municipality appointed an official "board of beauty" called "[Skönhetsrådet](/wiki/Stockholm_Beauty_Council "Stockholm Beauty Council")" in 1919 to protect and preserve the beauty of the city, still an active part of the city planning, and architecture debate in the city.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-102)^{#cite_ref-102}  

### Music {#Music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Music")\]

As the cultural centre of Sweden, Stockholm hosts much of Sweden's [influential music industry](/wiki/Music_of_Sweden "Music of Sweden"); the city hosts a variety of musical institutions and many of Sweden's most popular musicians come from Stockholm. Among these are world famous bands like [ABBA](/wiki/ABBA "ABBA"), as well as more modern musicians like Tim Bergling, more commonly called [Avicii](/wiki/Avicii "Avicii"). The most prestigious musical institutions in Stockholm include the [Royal Swedish Opera](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Opera "Royal Swedish Opera") and [Royal Swedish Academy of Music](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Academy_of_Music "Royal Swedish Academy of Music"), both founded in the late eighteenth century.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-103)^ Among Stockholm's most influential musical figures are [Carl Michael Bellman](/wiki/Carl_Michael_Bellman "Carl Michael Bellman"), [Joseph Martin Kraus](/wiki/Joseph_Martin_Kraus "Joseph Martin Kraus") and [Jenny Lind](/wiki/Jenny_Lind "Jenny Lind"); the former two were both classical composers, while the latter was one of Europe's most renowned opera singers.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-104)^{#cite_ref-104}

Stockholm first became globally prominent in modern music in the twentieth century. The band ABBA, one of the most popular in history, first became famous in the 1970s, after which they dominated popular music for about a decade, before becoming inactive.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)^ Other popular bands and musicians formed in the twentieth century include [Roxette](/wiki/Roxette "Roxette") and [Kent](/wiki/Kent_(band) "Kent (band)"), of which the former was most well known internationally while the latter remained popular in Sweden into the twenty-first century, when they ended the band in 2016.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

In the twenty-first century, Stockholm has played host to several influential musicians. [Max Martin](/wiki/Max_Martin "Max Martin"), who began his career in the late twentieth century, is one of the world's most influential songwriters; he remains based in Stockholm.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)^ Another popular musician was Tim Bergling, better known as Avicii, who became famous in 2013 for his electronic music; he committed suicide in 2018. Other popular modern musicians include [Robyn](/wiki/Robyn "Robyn"), as well as Eurovision winners [Måns Zelmerlöw](/wiki/M%C3%A5ns_Zelmerl%C3%B6w "Måns Zelmerlöw") and [Loreen](/wiki/Loreen "Loreen"). [Allsång på Skansen](/wiki/Alls%C3%A5ng_p%C3%A5_Skansen "Allsång på Skansen"), Sweden's most prominent music festival, is hosted in Stockholm.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}  

### Museums {#Museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Museums")\]  
Main article: [List of museums in Stockholm](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Stockholm "List of museums in Stockholm")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Vasa_Museum_interior1.jpg/220px-Vasa_Museum_interior1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vasa_Museum_interior1.jpg) The main hall of the [Vasa Museum](/wiki/Vasa_Museum "Vasa Museum") with a scale model of Vasa as it might have looked on its maiden voyage to the left and the preserved [ship itself](/wiki/Vasa_(ship) "Vasa (ship)") to the right [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Morag%C3%A5rden.jpg/220px-Morag%C3%A5rden.jpg)](/wiki/File:Morag%C3%A5rden.jpg) Moragården, one of many historical [homesteads](/wiki/Homestead_(buildings) "Homestead (buildings)") at the [Skansen](/wiki/Skansen "Skansen") [open-air museum](/wiki/Open-air_museum "Open-air museum")

Stockholm is one of the most crowded museum-cities in the world with around 100 museums, visited by millions of people every year.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}

The [Vasa Museum](/wiki/Vasa_Museum "Vasa Museum") ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Vasamuseet* ) is a [maritime museum](/wiki/Maritime_museum "Maritime museum") on [Djurgården](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rden "Djurgården") which displays the only almost fully intact 17th century [ship](/wiki/Ship "Ship") that has ever been salvaged, the 64-gun warship *[Vasa](/wiki/Vasa_(ship) "Vasa (ship)")* that sank on her maiden voyage in 1628.

The [Nationalmuseum](/wiki/Nationalmuseum "Nationalmuseum") houses the largest collection of art in the country: 16,000 paintings and 30,000 objects of art handicraft. The collection dates back to the days of Gustav Vasa in the 16th century, and has since been expanded with works by artists such as [Rembrandt](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt"), and [Antoine Watteau](/wiki/Jean-Antoine_Watteau "Jean-Antoine Watteau"), as well as constituting a main part of Sweden's art heritage, manifested in the works of [Alexander Roslin](/wiki/Alexander_Roslin "Alexander Roslin"), [Anders Zorn](/wiki/Anders_Zorn "Anders Zorn"), [Johan Tobias Sergel](/wiki/Johan_Tobias_Sergel "Johan Tobias Sergel"), [Carl Larsson](/wiki/Carl_Larsson "Carl Larsson"), [Carl Fredrik Hill](/wiki/Carl_Fredrik_Hill "Carl Fredrik Hill") and [Ernst Josephson](/wiki/Ernst_Josephson "Ernst Josephson"). From the year 2013 to 2018 the museum was closed due to a restoration of the building.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)^ [Moderna Museet](/wiki/Moderna_Museet "Moderna Museet") (Museum of Modern Art) is Sweden's national museum of [modern art](/wiki/Modern_art "Modern art"). It has works by noted modern artists such as [Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso") and [Salvador Dalí](/wiki/Salvador_Dal%C3%AD "Salvador Dalí").{#cite_ref-110}

[Skansen](/wiki/Skansen "Skansen") (in English: the [Sconce](/wiki/Sconce_(fortification) "Sconce (fortification)")) is a combined [open-air museum](/wiki/Open-air_museum "Open-air museum") and [zoo](/wiki/Zoo "Zoo"), located on the island of [Djurgården](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rden "Djurgården"). It was founded in 1891 by [Artur Hazelius](/wiki/Artur_Hazelius "Artur Hazelius") (1833--1901) to show the way of life in the [different parts of Sweden](/wiki/Provinces_of_Sweden "Provinces of Sweden") before the industrial era.

Other notable museums (in alphabetical order):

* [ABBA: The Museum](/wiki/ABBA:_The_Museum "ABBA: The Museum"), an interactive exhibit about the pop-group [ABBA](/wiki/ABBA "ABBA")
* [Swedish Army Museum](/wiki/Swedish_Army_Museum "Swedish Army Museum"), Swedish history, from 1500 to the present day with historical objects and realistic scenes
* [Fotografiska](/wiki/Fotografiska "Fotografiska"), a contemporary museum of photography, art and culture
* [Birka](/wiki/Birka "Birka"), The Viking City of Birka Swedish sites on the World Heritage List
* [Livrustkammaren](/wiki/Livrustkammaren "Livrustkammaren"), the royal armoury, located at [Stockholm Palace](/wiki/Stockholm_Palace "Stockholm Palace")
* [Maritime Museum (Stockholm)](/wiki/Maritime_Museum_(Stockholm) "Maritime Museum (Stockholm)"), museum for naval history, merchant shipping and shipbuilding.
* [Medelhavsmuseet](/wiki/Medelhavsmuseet "Medelhavsmuseet"), focused on the ancient cultures around the Mediterranean
* [Millesgården](/wiki/Millesg%C3%A5rden "Millesgården"), home of the sculptor Carl Milles and now a museum of his works
* [Museum of Far Eastern Antiquities](/wiki/Museum_of_Far_Eastern_Antiquities "Museum of Far Eastern Antiquities"), exciting mix of art and culture from [China](/wiki/China "China"), [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"), [Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea"), [India](/wiki/India "India") and [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia")
* [Swedish National Museum of Science and Technology](/wiki/Swedish_National_Museum_of_Science_and_Technology "Swedish National Museum of Science and Technology"), Sweden's largest museum of [technology](/wiki/Technology "Technology")
* [Nobel Museum](/wiki/Nobel_Museum "Nobel Museum"), devoted to the [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize"), [Nobel laureates](/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates "List of Nobel laureates"), and the founder of the prize, [Alfred Nobel](/wiki/Alfred_Nobel "Alfred Nobel") (1833--1896)
* [Nordic Museum](/wiki/Nordic_Museum "Nordic Museum"), dedicated to the cultural history and ethnography of Sweden
* [Royal Coin Cabinet](/wiki/Royal_Coin_Cabinet "Royal Coin Cabinet"), dedicated to the history of money and [economic history](/wiki/Economic_history "Economic history") in general
* [Skansen](/wiki/Skansen "Skansen"), The world's first open-air museum with 150 historic buildings, zoo with Nordic wild and domestic animals
* [Stockholm City Museum](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Museum "Stockholm City Museum"), a museum of 500 years of Sweden's history
* [Swedish History Museum](/wiki/Swedish_History_Museum "Swedish History Museum") magnificent medieval art and The History of Sweden exhibition which offers encounters
* [Swedish Museum of Natural History](/wiki/Swedish_Museum_of_Natural_History "Swedish Museum of Natural History"), Sweden's largest museum about new species and fossils of their predecessors in evolution.
* [Toy Museum Stockholm](/wiki/Toy_Museum_Stockholm "Toy Museum Stockholm") a museum of toys and collectables

### Art {#Art}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Art")\]

Stockholm has a vibrant art scene with a number of internationally recognised art centres and commercial galleries. Amongst others, privately sponsored initiatives such as [Bonniers](/wiki/Bonnier_Group "Bonnier Group") Konsthall, Magasin 3, and state-supported institutions such as [Tensta Konsthall](/wiki/Tensta_Konsthall "Tensta Konsthall") and Index all show leading international and national artists. In the last few years, a gallery district has emerged around Hudiksvallsgatan where leading galleries such as Andréhn-Schiptjenko, Brändström \& Stene have located. Other important commercial galleries include Nordenhake, [Milliken Gallery](/wiki/Milliken_Gallery "Milliken Gallery") and Galleri Magnus Karlsson. Stockholm also hosts the [Thiel Gallery](/wiki/Thiel_Gallery "Thiel Gallery"), founded by financier [Ernest Thiel](/wiki/Ernest_Thiel "Ernest Thiel") in the early twentieth century. The City of Stockholm also has its own art gallery and museum, [Liljevalchs konsthall](/wiki/Liljevalchs_konsthall "Liljevalchs konsthall"), with a well visited spring salon every year with works of art from professionals and amateurs; the art showed every spring is sent in anonymously and picked by a committee.  

### Suburbs {#Suburbs}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Suburbs")\]

The Stockholm suburbs are places with diverse cultural background. Some areas in the suburbs, including those of [Skärholmen](/wiki/Sk%C3%A4rholmen "Skärholmen"), [Tensta](/wiki/Tensta "Tensta"), [Jordbro](/wiki/Jordbro "Jordbro"), [Fittja](/wiki/Fittja "Fittja"), [Husby](/wiki/Husby,_Stockholm "Husby, Stockholm"), [Brandbergen](/wiki/Brandbergen "Brandbergen"), [Rinkeby](/wiki/Rinkeby "Rinkeby"), [Rissne](/wiki/Rissne "Rissne"), [Kista](/wiki/Kista "Kista"), [Hagsätra](/wiki/Hags%C3%A4tra "Hagsätra"), [Hässelby](/wiki/H%C3%A4sselby "Hässelby"), [Farsta](/wiki/Farsta_(borough) "Farsta (borough)"), [Rågsved](/wiki/R%C3%A5gsved "Rågsved"), [Flemingsberg](/wiki/Flemingsberg "Flemingsberg"), have high percentages of immigrants or second generation immigrants. These mainly come from the [Middle East](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East") ([Assyrian](/wiki/Assyrian_people "Assyrian people"), [Turks](/wiki/Turkish_people "Turkish people") and [Kurds](/wiki/Kurds "Kurds")) also Bosnians and Serbs, but there are also immigrants from Africa, [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia") and [Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America").^[\[111\]](#cite_note-111)^^[\[112\]](#cite_note-112)^ Other parts of the inner suburbs, such as Täby, Danderyd, Lidingö, Solna, Nacka and, as well as some of the suburbs mentioned above, have a majority of ethnic [Swedes](/wiki/Swedes "Swedes").{#cite_ref-112}  

### Theatre and music {#Theatre_and_music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Theatre and music")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Dramaten_050701.JPG/220px-Dramaten_050701.JPG)](/wiki/File:Dramaten_050701.JPG) [Royal Dramatic Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Dramatic_Theatre "Royal Dramatic Theatre"), one of Stockholm's many theatres

Distinguished among Stockholm's many theatres are the [Royal Dramatic Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Dramatic_Theatre "Royal Dramatic Theatre") (*Kungliga Dramatiska Teatern* ), one of Europe's most renowned theatres, and the [Royal Swedish Opera](/wiki/Royal_Swedish_Opera "Royal Swedish Opera"), inaugurated in 1773.

Other notable theatres are the [Stockholm City Theatre](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Theatre "Stockholm City Theatre") (Stockholms stadsteater), the Peoples Opera (*[Folkoperan](/wiki/Folkoperan "Folkoperan")* ), the Modern Theatre of Dance (*Moderna dansteatern* ), the [China Theatre](/wiki/Chinateatern "Chinateatern"), the [Göta Lejon](/wiki/G%C3%B6ta_Lejon "Göta Lejon") Theatre, the [Mosebacke](/wiki/Mosebacke "Mosebacke") Theatre, and the [Oscar Theatre](/wiki/Oscarsteatern "Oscarsteatern").

Premises for orchestral music and concerts include [Stockholm Concert Hall](/wiki/Stockholm_Concert_Hall "Stockholm Concert Hall") where for example the yearly awarding ceremony for the Nobel prize is held, and [The Berwald hall](/wiki/Berwald_Hall "Berwald Hall"), home to the National Radio Orchestra.

Influential rappers [Yung Lean](/wiki/Yung_Lean "Yung Lean") and [Bladee](/wiki/Bladee "Bladee") were born in and are currently based in Stockholm along with British-Swedish experimental artist \& designer [Ecco2K](/wiki/Ecco2K "Ecco2K").

Stockholm has hosted the [Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest "Eurovision Song Contest") three times, in 1975 at [Stockholmsmässan](/wiki/Stockholmsm%C3%A4ssan "Stockholmsmässan"), and in 2000 and 2016 at [Globe Arena](/wiki/Globe_Arena "Globe Arena").^[\[113\]](#cite_note-113)^^[\[114\]](#cite_note-114)^^[\[115\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}  

### Amusement park {#Amusement_park}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Amusement park")\]

[Gröna Lund](/wiki/Gr%C3%B6na_Lund "Gröna Lund") is an amusement park located on the island of [Djurgården](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rden "Djurgården"). This amusement park has over 30 attractions and many restaurants. It is a popular tourist attraction and visited by thousands of people every day. It is open from the end of April to the middle of September. Gröna Lund also serves as a concert venue.  

### Media {#Media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Media")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Vasabron_Riddarholmen_Norstedts.jpg/220px-Vasabron_Riddarholmen_Norstedts.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vasabron_Riddarholmen_Norstedts.jpg) Bookpublisher, [Norstedt Building](/wiki/Norstedt_Building "Norstedt Building"), seen from [Vasabron](/wiki/Vasabron "Vasabron"), in [Riddarholmen](/wiki/Riddarholmen "Riddarholmen")

Stockholm is the media centre of Sweden. It has four nationwide daily newspapers and is also the central location of the publicly funded radio ([SR](/wiki/Sveriges_Radio "Sveriges Radio")) and television ([SVT](/wiki/Sveriges_Television "Sveriges Television")). In addition, all other major television channels have their base in Stockholm, such as: [TV3](/wiki/TV3_(Viasat) "TV3 (Viasat)"), [TV4](/wiki/TV4_Group "TV4 Group") and [TV6](/wiki/TV6_(Sweden) "TV6 (Sweden)"). All major magazines are also located to Stockholm, as are the largest literature publisher, the [Bonnier group](/wiki/Bonnier_Group "Bonnier Group"). The world's best-selling video game *[Minecraft](/wiki/Minecraft "Minecraft")* was created in Stockholm by [Markus 'Notch' Persson](/wiki/Markus_Persson "Markus Persson") in 2009, and its company [Mojang](/wiki/Mojang "Mojang") is headquartered there.  

### Sports {#Sports}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
See also: [Football in Stockholm](/wiki/Football_in_Stockholm "Football in Stockholm")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Friends_Arena_from_inside.jpg/220px-Friends_Arena_from_inside.jpg)](/wiki/File:Friends_Arena_from_inside.jpg) [Strawberry Arena](/wiki/Strawberry_Arena "Strawberry Arena") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Bandyfinal2010_hammarby_celebration.jpg/220px-Bandyfinal2010_hammarby_celebration.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bandyfinal2010_hammarby_celebration.jpg) Scenes after [Hammarby](/wiki/Hammarby_IF_Bandy "Hammarby IF Bandy") won their first [national bandy title](/wiki/List_of_Swedish_bandy_champions "List of Swedish bandy champions") in 2010

The most popular spectator sports are [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") and [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey"). The three most popular football clubs in Stockholm are [AIK](/wiki/AIK_Fotboll "AIK Fotboll"), [Djurgårdens IF](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rdens_IF_Fotboll "Djurgårdens IF Fotboll") and [Hammarby IF](/wiki/Hammarby_Fotboll "Hammarby Fotboll"), who all play in the first tier, [Allsvenskan](/wiki/Allsvenskan "Allsvenskan"). [AIK](/wiki/AIK_Fotboll "AIK Fotboll") play at Sweden's [national stadium for football](/wiki/List_of_national_stadiums "List of national stadiums"), [Strawberry Arena](/wiki/Strawberry_Arena "Strawberry Arena") in [Solna](/wiki/Solna_Municipality "Solna Municipality"), with a capacity of 54,329. The [2017 UEFA Europa League Final](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Europa_League_Final "2017 UEFA Europa League Final") was played on 24 May between AFC Ajax and Manchester United at this arena. Manchester United won the trophy after a 2--0 victory.

Djurgårdens IF and [Hammarby](/wiki/Hammarby_IF "Hammarby IF") play at [Tele2 Arena](/wiki/Tele2_Arena "Tele2 Arena") in [Johanneshov](/wiki/Johanneshov "Johanneshov"), with a capacity of 30,000 spectators.

All three clubs are multi-sport clubs, which have ice hockey teams; [AIK](/wiki/AIK_IF "AIK IF") and [Djurgårdens IF](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rdens_IF_Hockey "Djurgårdens IF Hockey") play in [the second tier](/wiki/HockeyAllsvenskan "HockeyAllsvenskan") and Hammarby in [the third tier](/wiki/Hockeyettan "Hockeyettan"), as well as teams in [bandy](/wiki/Bandy "Bandy"), [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), [floorball](/wiki/Floorball "Floorball") and other sports, including individual sports.

Historically, the city was the host of the [1912 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1912_Summer_Olympics "1912 Summer Olympics"). From those days stem the [Stockholms Olympiastadion](/wiki/Stockholm_Olympic_Stadium "Stockholm Olympic Stadium") which has since hosted numerous sports events, notably football and athletics. Other major sports arenas are [Strawberry Arena](/wiki/Strawberry_Arena "Strawberry Arena"), the new national football stadium, [Avicii Arena](/wiki/Avicii_Arena "Avicii Arena") (colloquially called Globen), a multi-sport arena and one of the largest spherical buildings in the world and the nearby indoor arena [Hovet](/wiki/Hovet "Hovet").

Besides the 1912 Summer Olympics, Stockholm hosted the [1956 Summer Olympics Equestrian Games](/wiki/Equestrian_at_the_1956_Summer_Olympics "Equestrian at the 1956 Summer Olympics") and the [UEFA Euro 1992](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1992 "UEFA Euro 1992"). The city was also second runner up in the [2004 Summer Olympics bids](/wiki/Bids_for_the_2004_Summer_Olympics "Bids for the 2004 Summer Olympics"). Stockholm hosted the [1958 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1958_FIFA_World_Cup "1958 FIFA World Cup"). Stockholm recently bid jointly with [Åre](/wiki/%C3%85re "Åre") for the [2026 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2026_Winter_Olympics "2026 Winter Olympics") but lost out to the joint bid of [Milan](/wiki/Milan "Milan")/[Cortina d'Ampezzo](/wiki/Cortina_d%27Ampezzo "Cortina d'Ampezzo"), [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy"), if awarded it would have been the second city to host both Summer and Winter Olympics after [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing") and for the [2026 Winter Paralympics](/wiki/2026_Winter_Paralympics "2026 Winter Paralympics") and with [Åre](/wiki/%C3%85re "Åre") it would have also be to host all three winter event including [Winter Olympic Games](/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games "Winter Olympic Games"), [Winter Paralympic Games](/wiki/Winter_Paralympic_Games "Winter Paralympic Games") and the [Special Olympics World Winter Games](/wiki/Special_Olympics_World_Games "Special Olympics World Games") in which [Åre](/wiki/%C3%85re "Åre") would have host in 2021 along with [Östersund](/wiki/%C3%96stersund "Östersund"), however Sweden pulled out host the Special Olympic World Winter Games 2021 due to lack of funding instead it moved to [Kazan](/wiki/Kazan "Kazan"), [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia") and was delayed to 2022. Stockholm first bid for the Winter Olympics for [2022 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics "2022 Winter Olympics"), but withdrew its bid in 2014 due to financial matters.

Stockholm also hosted all but one of the [Nordic Games](/wiki/Nordic_Games "Nordic Games"), a winter [multi-sport event](/wiki/Multi-sport_event "Multi-sport event") that predated the [Winter Olympics](/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games "Winter Olympic Games").

In 2015, the Stockholms Kungar [Rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") club was formed. They are Stockholm's first Rugby league team and will play in Sweden's National Rugby league championship.

Every year Stockholm is host to the [ÖTILLÖ](/wiki/%C3%96till%C3%B6 "Ötillö") Swimrun World Championship.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

Stockholm has hosted the [Stockholm Open](/wiki/Stockholm_Open "Stockholm Open"), an [ATP World Tour 250 series](/wiki/ATP_World_Tour_250_series "ATP World Tour 250 series") professional [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis") tournament annually since 1969. Each year since 1995, the tournament has been hosted at the [Kungliga tennishallen](/wiki/Kungliga_tennishallen "Kungliga tennishallen").^[\[117\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}  

### Cuisine {#Cuisine}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Cuisine")\]

Dating back to at least the 1350s, [Storkällaren](/w/index.php?title=Stork%C3%A4llaren&action=edit&redlink=1 "Storkällaren (page does not exist)") or [Rådhuskällaren](/w/index.php?title=R%C3%A5dhusk%C3%A4llaren&action=edit&redlink=1 "Rådhuskällaren (page does not exist)") is Stockholm's oldest known place of [business](/wiki/Business "Business").^[\[118\]](#cite_note-118)^ Swedish 1700s [composer](/wiki/Composer "Composer") and [entertainer](/wiki/Entertainer "Entertainer") [Carl Michael Bellman](/wiki/Carl_Michael_Bellman "Carl Michael Bellman") was a frequent visitor to the city's [taverns](/wiki/Tavern "Tavern"), [inns](/wiki/Inn "Inn") and [wine cellars](/wiki/Wine_cellar "Wine cellar"). In his [poems](/wiki/Poetry "Poetry"), Bellman mentioned 113 taverns and inns in and around Stockholm, 30 of which were located in the Gamla Stan.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-119)^^\[*[unreliable source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Reliable sources")*\]^{#cite_ref-119}

In 2016, there were 3,315 [pubs](/wiki/Pub "Pub"), [cafes](/wiki/Coffeehouse "Coffeehouse") and [restaurants](/wiki/Restaurant "Restaurant") in the municipality of Stockholm.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-120)^ Among the most famous and acclaimed is the restaurant [Operakällaren](/wiki/Operak%C3%A4llaren "Operakällaren").{#cite_ref-120}

In Stockholm and its surroundings, only two historic [eateries](/wiki/Eateries "Eateries") remain operating in unbroken succession and in the same location: [Stallmästaregården](/wiki/Stallm%C3%A4stareg%C3%A5rden "Stallmästaregården") in [Solna](/wiki/Solna_Municipality "Solna Municipality"), dating back to the mid-17th century, and [Den Gyldene Freden](/wiki/Den_gyldene_freden "Den gyldene freden") in Gamla Stan, located at the same [address](/wiki/Address "Address") since 1722. "Freden" may thus be the world's oldest continuously existing city pub in the same location.  

### Yearly events and festivals {#Yearly_events_and_festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Yearly events and festivals")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Stockholm_Marathon.jpg/220px-Stockholm_Marathon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stockholm_Marathon.jpg) [Stockholm Marathon](/wiki/Stockholm_Marathon "Stockholm Marathon"), near [Kungsträdgården](/wiki/Kungstr%C3%A4dg%C3%A5rden "Kungsträdgården") in 2008

* [Stockholm Jazz Festival](/wiki/Stockholm_Jazz_Festival "Stockholm Jazz Festival") is one of Sweden's oldest festivals. The festival takes place at [Skeppsholmen](/wiki/Skeppsholmen "Skeppsholmen") in July.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)^{#cite_ref-121}
* [Stockholm Early Music Festival](/wiki/Stockholm_Early_Music_Festival "Stockholm Early Music Festival"), the largest international event for historical music in the Nordic countries. First week in June since 2002.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-122)^{#cite_ref-122}
* The [Stockholm Culture Festival](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm_Culture_Festival&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stockholm Culture Festival (page does not exist)") (Swedish: *Stockholms kulturfestival* ) is a free recurring cultural festival in August, which is held by the City of Stockholm. Runs in parallel with We Are Stockholm.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}
* [We Are Stockholm](/wiki/We_Are_Sthlm "We Are Sthlm") is a free youth festival people between 13 and 19 years. Runs in parallel with the Stockholm Culture Festival in August and is held by the City of Stockholm. Between 2001 and 2013, the festival went by the name Ung08.
* [Stockholm Pride](/wiki/Stockholm_Pride "Stockholm Pride") is the largest [LGBT Pride](/wiki/LGBT_Pride "LGBT Pride") event in the Nordic countries and takes place in the last week of July every year. The Stockholm Pride festival always ends with a parade and in 2007, 50,000 people marched with the parade and about 500,000 watched.
* The [Stockholm Marathon](/wiki/Stockholm_Marathon "Stockholm Marathon") takes place on a Saturday in early June each year.
* The [Nobel Banquet](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") takes place at [Stockholm City Hall](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Hall "Stockholm City Hall") every year on 10 December.
* The [Stockholm Water Festival](/wiki/Stockholm_Water_Festival "Stockholm Water Festival") (Swedish: *Vattenfestivalen* ) was a popular summer [festival](/wiki/Festival "Festival") held annually in Stockholm between 1991 and 1999.
* Manifestation, a yearly ecumenical Christian festival with up to 25,000 participants.
* [Summerburst Music festival](/w/index.php?title=Summerburst&action=edit&redlink=1 "Summerburst (page does not exist)")
* [The Stockholm International Film Festival](/wiki/Stockholm_International_Film_Festival "Stockholm International Film Festival") is an annual film festival held in Stockholm each year since 1990.

Environment {#Environment}
--------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Environment")\]  

### Green city with a national urban park {#Green_city_with_a_national_urban_park}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Green city with a national urban park")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Parkudden_djurgarden.jpg/220px-Parkudden_djurgarden.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parkudden_djurgarden.jpg) Park on the island of [Djurgården](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rden "Djurgården") in central Stockholm

Stockholm is one of the cleanest capitals in the world.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-124)^ The city was granted the 2010 [European Green Capital Award](/wiki/European_Green_Capital_Award "European Green Capital Award") by the [EU Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission"); this was Europe's first "green capital".^[\[125\]](#cite_note-ec.europa.eu-125)^ Applicant cities were evaluated in several ways: climate change, local transport, public green areas, air quality, noise, waste, water consumption, waste water treatment, sustainable utilisation of land, biodiversity and environmental management.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-international.stockholm.se-126)^ Out of 35 participant cities, eight finalists were chosen: Stockholm, [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam"), [Bristol](/wiki/Bristol "Bristol"), [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen"), [Freiburg](/wiki/Freiburg_im_Breisgau "Freiburg im Breisgau"), Hamburg, [Münster](/wiki/M%C3%BCnster "Münster"), and [Oslo](/wiki/Oslo "Oslo").^[\[127\]](#cite_note-August_2010-127)^ Some of the reasons why Stockholm won the 2010 European Green Capital Award were: its integrated administrative system, which ensures that environmental aspects are considered in budgets, operational planning, reporting, and monitoring; its cut in carbon dioxide emissions by 25% per capita in ten years; and its decision towards being fossil fuel free by 2050.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-international.stockholm.se-126)^ Stockholm has long demonstrated concern for the environment. The city's environmental program is the fifth since the first one was established in the mid-1970s.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-128)^ In 2011, Stockholm passed the title of European Green Capital to Hamburg, Germany.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-August_2010-127)^{#cite_ref-August_2010_127-1}  

#### Role model {#Role_model}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Role model")\]

At the beginning of 2010, Stockholm launched the program Professional Study Visits^[\[129\]](#cite_note-129)^ in order to share the city's green best practices. The program provides visitors with the opportunity to learn how to address issues such as waste management, urban planning, carbon dioxide emissions, and sustainable and efficient transportation system, among others.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-ec.europa.eu-125)^{#cite_ref-ec.europa.eu_125-1}

According to the European Cities Monitor 2010,^[\[130\]](#cite_note-130)^ Stockholm is the best city in terms of freedom from pollution. Surrounded by 219 nature reserves, Stockholm has around 1,000 green spaces, which corresponds to 30% of the city's area.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Environment_2010-131)^ Founded in 1995, the [Royal National City Park](/wiki/Royal_National_City_Park "Royal National City Park") is the world's first legally protected "national urban park".^[\[132\]](#cite_note-132)^^[\[133\]](#cite_note-133)^ For a description of the formation process, value assets and implementation of the legal protection of The Royal National Urban Park, see [Schantz 2006](http://gih.diva-portal.org/smash/record.jsf?searchId=1&pid=diva2:528) The water in Stockholm is so clean that people can dive and fish in the centre of the city.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Environment_2010-131)^ The waters of downtown Stockholm serve as spawning grounds for multiple fish species including trout and salmon, though human intervention is needed to keep populations up.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-134)^ Regarding CO~2~ emissions, the government's target is that Stockholm will be CO~2~ free before 2050.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Environment_2010-131)^{#cite_ref-Environment_2010_131-2}  

### Air quality {#Air_quality}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Air quality")\]

Stockholm used to have problematic levels of particulates (PM10) due to studded winter tires, but by the 2010s they were below limits, after street-specific bans.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)^ Nitrogen oxides emitted by diesel vehicles were a problem in the 2010s, but by 2021 they were again below limits, after electric cars had started to replace diesel-driven ones, and pollution regulations for lorries had tightened. As of 2021, the pollutant that exceeds limits is ozone, due to global pollution. In 2021 the average levels for urban background (roof of Torkel Knutssonsgatan on Södermalm) were: [NO~2~](/wiki/Nitrogen_dioxide "Nitrogen dioxide") 9.7 μg/m^3^, [PM10](/wiki/Particulates "Particulates") 9.5 μg/m^3^, PM2.5 5.1 μg/m^3^, [soot](/wiki/Soot "Soot") 0.36 μg/m^3^, [ultrafine particles](/wiki/Ultrafine_particle "Ultrafine particle") 6100/cm^3^, [SO~2~](/wiki/Sulfur_dioxide "Sulfur dioxide") 0.4 μg/m^3^, [ozone](/wiki/Ozone "Ozone") 53 μg/m^3^. For urban street level (the densely trafficked Hornsgatan on Södermalm) the average levels were: NO~2~ 23 μg/m^3^, PM10 17 μg/m^3^, PM2.5 6.0 μg/m^3^, soot 0.55 μg/m^3^.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-136)^{#cite_ref-136}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Stockholm](/wiki/Transport_in_Stockholm "Transport in Stockholm")  

### Public transportation {#Public_transportation}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Public transportation")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/SL_C20_Gamla_Stan%2C_Stockholm.jpg/220px-SL_C20_Gamla_Stan%2C_Stockholm.jpg)](/wiki/File:SL_C20_Gamla_Stan,_Stockholm.jpg) A southbound full-length (3 car) [C20 metrotrain](/wiki/Bombardier_C20 "Bombardier C20") departing from the [Gamla Stan station](/wiki/Gamla_stan_metro_station "Gamla stan metro station")

Stockholm has an extensive [public transport](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport") system. It consists of the [Stockholm Metro](/wiki/Stockholm_Metro "Stockholm Metro") ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Tunnelbanan* ), which consist of three colour-coded main systems (green, red and blue) with seven lines (10, 11, 13, 14, 17, 18, 19); the [Stockholm commuter rail](/wiki/Stockholm_commuter_rail "Stockholm commuter rail") ([Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language"): *Pendeltåget* ) which runs on the state-owned railroads on six lines (40, 41, 42, 43, 44, 48); four [light rail/tramway lines](/wiki/Trams_in_Stockholm "Trams in Stockholm") ([7](/wiki/Sp%C3%A5rv%C3%A4g_City "Spårväg City"), [12](/wiki/Nockebybanan "Nockebybanan"), [21](/wiki/Liding%C3%B6banan "Lidingöbanan"), and [22](/wiki/Tv%C3%A4rbanan "Tvärbanan")); the [891 mm](/wiki/Swedish_three_foot_gauge_railways "Swedish three foot gauge railways") [narrow-gauge railway](/wiki/Narrow-gauge_railway "Narrow-gauge railway") [Roslagsbanan](/wiki/Roslagsbanan "Roslagsbanan"), on three lines (27, 28, 29) in the northeastern part; the local railway [Saltsjöbanan](/wiki/Saltsj%C3%B6banan "Saltsjöbanan"), on two lines (25, 26) in the southeastern part; a large number of bus lines, and the inner-city [Djurgården ferry](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rden_ferry "Djurgården ferry"). The overwhelming majority of the land-based public transport in Stockholm County (save for the airport buses/[airport express trains](/wiki/Arlanda_Express "Arlanda Express") and other few commercially viable bus lines) is organized under the common umbrella of [Storstockholms Lokaltrafik](/wiki/Storstockholms_Lokaltrafik "Storstockholms Lokaltrafik") (SL), an *[aktiebolag](/wiki/Aktiebolag "Aktiebolag")* wholly owned by [Stockholm County Council](/wiki/Stockholm_County_Council "Stockholm County Council"). Since the 1990s, the operation and maintenance of the SL public transport services are contracted out to independent companies bidding for contracts, such as [MTR](/wiki/MTR_Corporation "MTR Corporation"), which operate the Metro. The archipelago boat traffic is handled by [Waxholmsbolaget](/wiki/Waxholmsbolaget "Waxholmsbolaget"), which is also wholly owned by the County Council.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Number_7_tram_bound_for_Sergels_Torg_in_Stockholm_Sweden.png/220px-Number_7_tram_bound_for_Sergels_Torg_in_Stockholm_Sweden.png)](/wiki/File:Number_7_tram_bound_for_Sergels_Torg_in_Stockholm_Sweden.png) An [A34 tram](/wiki/Bombardier_Flexity_Classic "Bombardier Flexity Classic") on [line 7](/wiki/Sp%C3%A5rv%C3%A4g_City "Spårväg City") at [Djurgårdsbron](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rdsbron "Djurgårdsbron")

SL has a common ticket system in the entire Stockholm County, which allows for easy travel between different modes of transport. The tickets are of two main types, single ticket and [travel cards](/wiki/Travel_card "Travel card"), both allowing for unlimited travel with SL in the entire Stockholm County for the duration of the ticket validity. On 1 April 2007, a zone system (A, B, C) and price system was introduced. Single tickets were available in forms of cash ticket, individual unit pre-paid tickets, pre-paid ticket slips of 8, SMS-ticket and machine ticket. Cash tickets bought at the point of travel were the most expensive and pre-paid tickets slips of 8 are the cheapest. A single ticket costs SEK 32 with the card and SEK 45 without and is valid for 75 minutes. The duration of the travel card validity depended on the exact type; they were available from 24 hours up to a year. As of 2018, a 30-day card costs SEK 860. Tickets of all these types were available with reduced prices for students and persons under 20 and over 65 years of age. On 9 January 2017, the zone system was removed, and the cost of the tickets was increased.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}  

#### The City Line Project {#The_City_Line_Project}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: The City Line Project")\]  
Main article: [Stockholm City Line](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Line "Stockholm City Line")

With an estimated cost of SEK 16.8 billion (January 2007 price level), which equals 2.44 billion US dollars, the [City Line](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Line "Stockholm City Line"), an environmentally certified project, comprises a 6 km (3.7 mi)-long commuter train tunnel (in rock and water) beneath Stockholm, with two new stations (Stockholm City and Stockholm Odenplan), and a 1.4 km (0.87 mi)-long railway bridge at [Årsta](/wiki/Enskede-%C3%85rsta "Enskede-Årsta"). The City Line was built by the Swedish Transport Administration in co-operation with the City of Stockholm, Stockholm County Council, and Stockholm Transport, SL. As [Stockholm Central Station](/wiki/Stockholm_Central_Station "Stockholm Central Station") is overloaded, the purpose of this project was to double the city's track capacity and improve service efficiency. Operations began in July 2017.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-trafikverket1-138)^^[\[139\]](#cite_note-139)^{#cite_ref-139}

Between [Riddarholmen](/wiki/Riddarholmen "Riddarholmen") and Söder Mälarstrand, the City Line runs through a submerged concrete tunnel.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-trafikverket1-138)^ As a green project, the City Line includes the purification of waste water; noise reduction through sound-attenuating tracks; the use of synthetic diesel, which provides users with clean air; and the recycling of excavated rocks.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-trafikverket1-138)^{#cite_ref-trafikverket1_138-2}  

### Roads {#Roads}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Roads")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Norra_L%C3%A4nken_nov_2016.jpg/220px-Norra_L%C3%A4nken_nov_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:Norra_L%C3%A4nken_nov_2016.jpg) [Norra länken](/wiki/Norra_l%C3%A4nken "Norra länken") (North link) motorway in Stockholm

Stockholm is at the junction of the [European routes](/wiki/International_E-road_network "International E-road network") [E4](/wiki/European_route_E4 "European route E4"), [E18](/wiki/European_route_E18 "European route E18") and [E20](/wiki/European_route_E20 "European route E20"). A [half-completed motorway ring road](/wiki/Stockholm_Ring_Road "Stockholm Ring Road") exists on the south, west and north sides of the City Centre. The northern section of the ring road, Norra Länken, opened for traffic in 2015 while the final subsea eastern section is being discussed as a future project. A bypass motorway for traffic between Northern and Southern Sweden, [Förbifart Stockholm](/wiki/F%C3%B6rbifart_Stockholm "Förbifart Stockholm"), is being built. The many islands and waterways make extensions of the road system both complicated and expensive, and new motorways are often built as systems of tunnels and bridges.  

#### Congestion charges {#Congestion_charges}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Congestion charges")\]  
Main article: [Stockholm congestion tax](/wiki/Stockholm_congestion_tax "Stockholm congestion tax")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Betalstation_2010.jpg/220px-Betalstation_2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Betalstation_2010.jpg) A control point for the congestion charge leading up to [Essingeleden](/wiki/Essingeleden "Essingeleden")

Stockholm has a [congestion pricing](/wiki/Congestion_pricing "Congestion pricing") system, the Stockholm congestion tax,^[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)^ in use on a permanent basis since 1 August 2007,^[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)^^[\[142\]](#cite_note-142)^ after having had a seven-month trial period in the first half of 2006.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-143)^ The City Centre is within the congestion tax zone. All the entrances and exits of this area have unmanned control points operating with [automatic number plate recognition](/wiki/Automatic_number_plate_recognition "Automatic number plate recognition"). All vehicles entering or exiting the congestion tax affected area, with a few exceptions, have to pay 10--20 [SEK](/wiki/Swedish_krona "Swedish krona") (1.09--2.18 [EUR](/wiki/Euro "Euro"), 1.49--2.98 [USD](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")) depending on the time of day between 06:30 and 18:29. The maximum tax amount per vehicle per day is SEK 60 (EUR 6.53).^[\[144\]](#cite_note-144)^ Payment is done by various means within 14 days after one has passed one of the control points; one cannot pay at the control points.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-145)^{#cite_ref-145}

After the trial period was over, consultative referendums were held in Stockholm Municipality and several other municipalities in Stockholm County. The then-reigning government ([Persson Cabinet](/wiki/Persson_Cabinet "Persson Cabinet")) stated that they would only take into consideration the results of the referendum in [Stockholm Municipality](/wiki/Stockholm_Municipality "Stockholm Municipality"). The opposition parties ([Alliance for Sweden](/wiki/Alliance_(Sweden) "Alliance (Sweden)")) stated that if they were to form a cabinet after the [general election](/wiki/2006_Swedish_general_election "2006 Swedish general election")---which was held the same day as the congestion tax referendums---they would take into consideration the referendums held in several of the other municipalities in [Stockholm County](/wiki/Stockholm_County "Stockholm County") as well. The results of the referendums were that the Stockholm Municipality voted for the congestion tax, while the other municipalities voted against it. The opposition parties won the general election and a few days before they formed government ([Reinfeldt Cabinet](/wiki/Reinfeldt_Cabinet "Reinfeldt Cabinet")) they announced that the congestion tax would be reintroduced in Stockholm, but that the revenue would go entirely to road construction in and around Stockholm. During the trial period and according to the agenda of the previous government the revenue went entirely to public transport.  

### Ferries {#Ferries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Ferries")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Viking_Grace_in_Stockholm.jpg/220px-Viking_Grace_in_Stockholm.jpg)](/wiki/File:Viking_Grace_in_Stockholm.jpg) [*Viking Grace*](/wiki/MS_Viking_Grace "MS Viking Grace"), one of many [cruiseferries](/wiki/Cruiseferry "Cruiseferry") on the routes to [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland") and [Åland](/wiki/%C3%85land "Åland")

Stockholm has regular ferry lines to [Helsinki](/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki") and [Turku](/wiki/Turku "Turku") in Finland (commonly called "[Finlandsfärjan](/wiki/Baltic_Sea_cruiseferries "Baltic Sea cruiseferries")"); [Mariehamn](/wiki/Mariehamn "Mariehamn"), [Åland](/wiki/%C3%85land "Åland"); [Tallinn](/wiki/Tallinn "Tallinn"), Estonia; Riga, Latvia, and to [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg") in Russia. The large [Stockholm archipelago](/wiki/Stockholm_archipelago "Stockholm archipelago") is served by the archipelago boats of [Waxholmsbolaget](/wiki/Waxholmsbolaget "Waxholmsbolaget") (owned and subsidized by Stockholm County Council). Additionally, there are many for-profit private companies offering tours and regular service in the archipelago.  

### City bikes {#City_bikes}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: City bikes")\]

Between April and October, during the warmer months, it is possible to rent [Stockholm City Bikes](/wiki/Stockholm_City_Bikes "Stockholm City Bikes") by purchasing a bike card online or through retailers.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-146)^ Cards allow users to rent bikes from any Stockholm City Bikes stand spread across the city and return them in any stand.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-citybikes1-147)^ There are two types of cards: the Season Card (valid from 1 April to 31 October) and the 3-day card. When their validity runs out they can be reactivated and are therefore reusable.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-148)^ Bikes can be used for up to three hours per loan and can be rented from Monday to Sunday from 6 am to 10 pm.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-citybikes1-147)^ These bikes have unfortunately not been a huge success because of people throwing them into the water or destroying them. Although the city bikes are not the only victims of this, [e-scooters](/wiki/Motorized_scooter "Motorized scooter") get similar treatment.{#cite_ref-citybikes1_147-1}

[class=notpageimage\|](/wiki/File:Sweden_location_map,_40south.svg "File:Sweden location map, 40south.svg") Map showing the locations of airports around Stockholm

* International and domestic:
  * [Stockholm Arlanda Airport](/wiki/Stockholm_Arlanda_Airport "Stockholm Arlanda Airport") ([IATA](/wiki/IATA_airport_code "IATA airport code"): **ARN** , [ICAO](/wiki/ICAO_airport_code "ICAO airport code"): **ESSA** ) is the largest and busiest airport in Sweden with 27 million passengers in 2017. It is located about 40 km (25 mi) north of Stockholm and serves as a hub for [Scandinavian Airlines](/wiki/Scandinavian_Airlines "Scandinavian Airlines").
  * [Stockholm Bromma Airport](/wiki/Stockholm_Bromma_Airport "Stockholm Bromma Airport") ([IATA](/wiki/IATA_airport_code "IATA airport code"): **BMA** , [ICAO](/wiki/ICAO_airport_code "ICAO airport code"): **ESSB** ) is located about 8 km (5.0 mi) west of Stockholm, also serves as a hub for [BRA](/wiki/Braathens_Regional_Airlines "Braathens Regional Airlines") (Braathens Regional Airlines).
* Only international:
  * [Stockholm Skavsta Airport](/wiki/Stockholm_Skavsta_Airport "Stockholm Skavsta Airport") ([IATA](/wiki/IATA_airport_code "IATA airport code"): **NYO** , [ICAO](/wiki/ICAO_airport_code "ICAO airport code"): **ESKN** ) is located 108 km (67 mi) south of Stockholm. It is located 5 km (3 mi) away from [Södermanland County](/wiki/S%C3%B6dermanland_County "Södermanland County") capital [Nyköping](/wiki/Nyk%C3%B6ping "Nyköping").
  * [Stockholm Västerås Airport](/wiki/Stockholm_V%C3%A4ster%C3%A5s_Airport "Stockholm Västerås Airport") ([IATA](/wiki/IATA_airport_code "IATA airport code"): **VST** , [ICAO](/wiki/ICAO_airport_code "ICAO airport code"): **ESOW** ) is located 103 km (64 mi) west of Stockholm, in the city of [Västerås](/wiki/V%C3%A4ster%C3%A5s "Västerås").

The *[Arlanda Express](/wiki/Arlanda_Express "Arlanda Express")* [airport rail link](/wiki/Airport_rail_link "Airport rail link") runs between [Arlanda Airport](/wiki/Arlanda_North_Station "Arlanda North Station") and [Stockholm Central Station](/wiki/Stockholm_Central_Station "Stockholm Central Station"). With a journey of 20 minutes, the train ride is the fastest way of travelling to the city centre. [Arlanda Central Station](/wiki/Arlanda_Central_Station "Arlanda Central Station") is also served by commuter, regional and intercity trains.

Additionally, there are also bus lines, [Flygbussarna](/wiki/Flygbussarna "Flygbussarna"), that run between central Stockholm and all the airports.

As of 2010^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit)^ there are no airports specifically for [general aviation](/wiki/General_aviation "General aviation") in the Stockholm area.  

### Inter-city trains {#Inter-city_trains}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Inter-city trains")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Stockholm_centralstation_2017_-1_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Stockholm_centralstation_2017_-1_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stockholm_centralstation_2017_-1_(cropped).jpg) [Stockholm Central Station](/wiki/Stockholm_Central_Station "Stockholm Central Station")

[Stockholm Central Station](/wiki/Stockholm_Central_Station "Stockholm Central Station") has train connections to many Swedish cities as well as to [Oslo, Norway](/wiki/Oslo_Central_Station "Oslo Central Station"), [Copenhagen, Denmark](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Station "Copenhagen Central Station") and [Hamburg, Germany](/wiki/Hamburg_Hauptbahnhof "Hamburg Hauptbahnhof"). The popular [X 2000](/wiki/X_2000 "X 2000") service to [Gothenburg](/wiki/Gothenburg "Gothenburg") takes three hours. Most of the trains are run by [SJ AB](/wiki/SJ_AB "SJ AB").  

International rankings {#International_rankings}
------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Stockholm&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: International rankings")\]

Stockholm often performs well in international rankings, some of which are mentioned below:

* In the book *The Ultimate Guide to International Marathons* (1997), written by Dennis Craythorn and Rich Hanna, [Stockholm Marathon](/wiki/Stockholm_Marathon "Stockholm Marathon") is ranked as the best [marathon](/wiki/Marathon "Marathon") in the world.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-149)^{#cite_ref-149}
* In the 2006 [European Innovation Scoreboard](/wiki/European_Innovation_Scoreboard "European Innovation Scoreboard"), prepared by the [Maastricht Economic Research Institute on Innovation and Technology](/wiki/Maastricht_Economic_Research_Institute_on_Innovation_and_Technology "Maastricht Economic Research Institute on Innovation and Technology") (MERIT) and the [Joint Research Centre](/wiki/Joint_Research_Centre "Joint Research Centre")'s [Institute for the Protection and the Security of the Citizen](/wiki/Institute_for_the_Protection_and_the_Security_of_the_Citizen "Institute for the Protection and the Security of the Citizen") of the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission"), Stockholm was ranked as the most [innovative](/wiki/Innovation "Innovation") city in Europe.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-150)^{#cite_ref-150}
* In the 2008 World Knowledge Competitiveness Index, published by the Centre for International Competitiveness, Stockholm was ranked as the sixth most [competitive](/wiki/Competition_(companies) "Competition (companies)") region in the world and the most competitive region outside the United States.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-151)^{#cite_ref-151}
* In the 2006 European Regional Growth Index (E-REGI), published by [Jones Lang LaSalle](/wiki/JLL_(company) "JLL (company)"), Stockholm was ranked fifth on the list of European cities with the strongest [GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") growth forecast. Stockholm was ranked first in Scandinavia and second outside Central and Eastern Europe.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-152)^{#cite_ref-152}
* In the 2007 European Cities Monitor, published by [Cushman \& Wakefield](/wiki/Cushman_%26_Wakefield "Cushman & Wakefield"), Stockholm was ranked as the best Nordic city to locate a business. In the same report, Stockholm was ranked first in Europe in terms of freedom from [pollution](/wiki/Pollution "Pollution").^[\[153\]](#cite_note-153)^{#cite_ref-153}
* In a 2007 survey performed by the environmental economist [Matthew Kahn](/wiki/Matthew_Kahn "Matthew Kahn") for the *[Reader's Digest](/wiki/Reader%27s_Digest "Reader's Digest")* magazine, Stockholm was ranked first on its list of the "greenest" and most "livable" cities in the world.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}
* In a 2008 survey published by *Reader's Digest* magazine, Stockholm was ranked fourth in the world in its list of the "world's top ten honest cities".^[\[155\]](#cite_note-155)^{#cite_ref-155}
* In a 2008 survey published by the *[National Geographic Traveler](/wiki/National_Geographic_Traveler "National Geographic Traveler")* magazine, Gamla Stan (the Old Town) in Stockholm was ranked sixth on its list of rated historic places.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}
* In a 2008 survey published by the *[Foreign Policy](/wiki/Foreign_Policy "Foreign Policy")* magazine, Stockholm was ranked twenty-fourth on its list of the world's most global cities.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-The_2008_Global_Cities_Index-157)^{#cite_ref-The_2008_Global_Cities_Index_157-0}
* In 2009 Stockholm was awarded the title as European Green Capital 2010, as the first Green capital ever in the [European Green Capital Award](/wiki/European_Green_Capital_Award "European Green Capital Award") scheme.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}
* In 2013, Stockholm was named the 8th most competitive city in the world by the [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit").^[\[159\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}
* In 2016 Stockholm was one of the cities with the most [unicorn companies](/wiki/Unicorn_(finance) "Unicorn (finance)") in the world.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}
* In 2019 Stockholm was awarded the World Smart City Award in the city category for its leadership of the European Smart Cities and Communities project GrowSmarter.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-161)^{#cite_ref-161}
